text:
These have become my default pancakes.  I made them again this morning.  Use the old baker's tricks of letting your buttermilk, milk and eggs sit out for an hour before baking to get to room tempurature and you'll get increased fluff on these.  And don't overmix.  Be sure to leave small lumps of flour that break open when pouring out the mix on the griddle.  I used blueberries today and they turned out great - coat any fruit you want to add in a bit of the flour mixture first and you'll find they don't all drop to the bottom.  Great recipe.  Thanks.

country:

text:
It took a little tweaking and A LOT of time, but these did come out wonderful in the end.  Like other reviewers, this made WAY more than the listed 12 five inch pancakes!!  I could easily have fed my 5 family members with just 1/3 of the batter.  The first batch I made (exactly as the recipe is written) weren't stellar.  I found them to be heavy and strikingly like French Toast.  (They DID make pretty good waffles as I had a TON of batter leftover.)

On my next batch (scaled down to 1/3) I added one extra teaspoon of sugar and one teaspoon of lemon juice.  My trick for getting these nice and fluffy was to let the batter sit for a day or two in the refrigerator.  The oxidation of the lemon juice and baking soda really caused the batter to swell with all those wonderful air bubbles that make a nice, tender and fluffy pancake.  Making this on Sunday night and using it during the week has made this recipe a staple in my home.  My family can't get enough of them!!

text:
Yum!  I was out of buttermilk so I put about 1 tsp of vinegar (or you can use lemon juice) in the one cup measuring cup and then filled with milk.  By the time I was ready to mix the two together, I had "buttermilk".  I scaled the recipe for "4" rather than "12" because I was alone but I barely ate half of them.  I didn't even use a fork, I just poured the syrup on a plate and dipped!  Piggy, don't you think?  :)  I am saving the rest for tomorrow and will just toast them in the toaster-oven.  Can't wait!

text:
These were pretty good.  Thank heaven for another reviewer's suggestion for using whole milk, because I only had 2 cups of buttermilk!  I would, however, make one tiny suggestion: When adding all the wet ingredients together, make sure the butter has cooled somewhat, so as not to "cook" the eggs in the batter.  You'll wind up with super lumpy pancake batter!  You could also add the butter to the milk first, mix, then add the eggs, but DO NOT ADD THE BUTTER RIGHT OFF THE STOVE if you've already added the eggs!  I also added some vanilla for extra flavor.  Light, fluffy, and yummy!

text:
FLUFFY, LIGHT and HEAVENLY! Buttermilk is the key so don't substitute it! (I can't drink the stuff so I use the leftover buttermilk for Irish Soda Bread.) You need medium heat and I had to experiment with it the first time. Just remember your stove setting for next time. Cook each side for about two minutes (make a note of the cook time too!). At various times I've tried adding very ripe bananas, or chocolate chips (made a yucky mess), or nutmeg or cinnamon. But to me they are best as is with just a pat of REAL butter and REAL maple syrup. Leftovers can be refrigerated but I've found they can't be brought back to full life (kinda like zombies...they'll only be a reflection of their former glory).

city:

country:
None
text:
I was looking for a 'best-of' buttermilk pancake recipe and decided to do a head-to-head comparison between Buttermilk Pancakes II and the Truck-Stop Pancake recipe.
I made both recipes simultaneously using all ROOM TEMPERATURE wet ingredients as per another pancake review on this site.
Cooking was done on an electric grill at 350F and I converted both recipes down to 4-5 servings.
Findings:
Although color and loft were great on both recipes, both myself and my wife found the Buttermilk Pancakes II to be far superior in both texture and flavor.
The Truck Stop pancakes had too much baking powder and soda taste as well as a slightly tougher consistency. An added benefit to BP II was the ease that it converted up or down. These are the best buttermilk pancakes I have found so far, I suspect that using room temperature ingredients mixed lightly with a whisk contributed to the batter's slightly stiff consistency. I highly recommend this recipe. JM

text:
this is pretty much the same recipe i have been using for years.   Absolutely, do not overmix, that makes pancakes leathery.  The buttermilk quantity listed is a little high and you don't need milk at all...mixed this way, the batter will be kinda runny from my perspective... so add the milk mixture with a gentle hand and thats why i gave only 4 stars.  I use more sugar and leave out the butter to cut fat except for special occasions.  You can swap out the all purpose flour for either cake flour or white lily for an interesting change... cakey-er. Oh, i also scale my recipe for two:  1 C flour, 1 tsp baking powder, 1/2 tsp soda, scant 1/2 tsp salt, 2 tbl sugar, 1 egg, 3/4+ C buttermilk

text:
WOW!  These are THE BEST buttermilk pancakes I have ever tasted!!  Much better than the Buttermilk Pancake I and Good Old Fashioned Pancake from this site.  I should've just started with this one!  These are super light, fluffy, sooo moist and perfectly sweet.  This does make a lot of batter, but just refredigerate the extra batter and they taste just as perfect the next day.  As the recipe says, do NOT over mix.  There will still be lumps and do NOT change or half the recipe or it won't turn out.  The ONLY addition I would make is to add about 1 1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract.  This will be my MASTER RECIPE from now on.  Look no further for the ulitmate, gourmet pancake.  Buy a bag of frozen blueberries and keep it in the freezer for whenever you want blueberry pancakes- they're too die for.  SO DELISH- forget the box stuff!

country:
None
text:
My family have become pancake connoisseurs over the years as they are definitely our favourite breakfast.  We have tried recipes from all over the world, but this ranks among the best.  They're so light and fluffy and brown to a lovely light honey color.

We love them served with plain ol' maple syrup or berry yoghurt and fresh blueberries.

Experimentation has shown that if you separate the egg whites and beat them  until they form stiff peaks and then fold them through the mix just before pouring, it adds to the fluffiness and texture.  Also, it doesn't hurt to leave the egg/buttermilk mixture a while to reach room temp.  And also, it helps to leave the final mixture stand a little while before pouring.  (While you make the coffee and whip the fresh cream!)

userID:
1862670
Display Name:
Ron S.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I use a similar recipe for myself cutting it down by two-thirds to 1 cup of flour, 1 tbsp. of sugar, 1 tsp. of baking powder, 1/4 tsp. of salt, 1 cup of stirred vanilla yogurt, 1 egg, a  1/4 cup of milk and 1 tbsp. of melted butter. Mix in order as directed in the directions given. I usually mix up the dry ingredients in the recipe in bulk and store in a large air-tight container ahead of time. Then it is just mixing 1 tbsp. of melted butter with 1 slightly scrambled egg in a large mixing bowl. Add 1 cup of vanilla yogurt and 1/4 cup of milk. Mix thoroughly. Then add 1 cup of dry ingredients. Stir until dry ingredients are just moistened. Mixture should be lumpy. You can adjust consistency to your liking by adding more milk to thin out or more dry ingredients to thicken. I use a 1/4 cup measuring cup to ladle the batter onto a hot flat griddle pan (Heating element is set at medium high). For blueberry pancakes, just dot the top of the pancakes with fresh or frozen blueberries just after ladling the batter onto the hot pan. When bottom of pancake is dark golden brown, flip over to cook the other side of the pancakes. When done, stack on a warm plate, kept warm in a low (150 deg. F) oven. When the entire batter in finished, enjoy pancakes with thin slices of butter inserted between the pancakes and top off with table syrup.

text:
This is an absolutely fantastic recipe.  The pancakes are truly a work of art.  Fluffy as a pillow and you can't beat this buttermilk base.  I took a few posted suggestions, such as reducing the ingredients by half, adding an extra 1 tsp. sugar, 1 tsp. lemon juice, and a tsp. of vanilla. By barely mixing the wet and dry ingredients together, it produced a batter that was very puffy and light. This will be my ONLY pancake recipe for now on.

text:
I Love this recipe!  I made my own buttermilk with lemon juice and added a little bit more sugar.  I tasted the first pancake and tasted the egg, maybe it was just me!  I added maple syrup to my mix and they were perfect!  I usually add syrup to my batter but wanted to try one without it first.  I do not like syrup ON my pancakes but IN them is fine!  It gives a sweet taste without the mess.  I also add syrup to the egg mixture of my french toast for the same reason.  I love how much batter was left over.  In the morning all I have to do is cook.  My pan is on the stove waiting for morning!  Thank you for this recipe!

text:
Delicious! I scaled this down a bit as there were only two of us this morning. I had no problems mixing the batter up and pouring it onto the grill. I used all fresh buttermilk.  The pancakes rose up nicely while little air bubbles popped on the surface. I cooked these until a light golden brown color appeared before flipping them over. These were indeed light, fluffy and tasty! I love that this recipe requires fresh buttermilk as this is what I would have used anyway in my pancakes. The buttermilk and butter both add a nice flavor to the pancakes. I don't think this recipe needs any adjustments and is good as is. I think next time I might even add some fresh blueberries to the batter. Today, we drizzled some warm, "Blueberry and Raspberry Pancake Topping," from this website, over the pancakes. Even thou I cut back on the amount I still ended up with 11 medium size pancakes which left us enough to enjoy again for tomorrow morning's breakfast!

text:
This is the holy grail of buttermilk pancake recipes -- FABULOUS!  The pancakes cook up nice and high and fluffy without the heaviness or "doughiness" you sometimes get with thicker pancakes.  I've tried just about every pancake recipe out there.  This one is THE BEST, without a doubt.  This recipe yielded about 20 good size pancakes.  One thing I especially liked was that the batter remained stable right down to the last pancake.  Sometimes as you get near the last of a pancake batter, it'll be runnier and produce thinner pancakes.  Not so with this recipe -- perfect from beginning to end.  THANK YOU for this fantastic, absolutely scrumptious recipe! :)

text:
100x better than the recipe I usually use - you know, the one on the back of the box?! I scaled the recipe to 8 servings then kept most measurements as written except: used 2-1/2 tablespoons sugar (increased a tad), 1/4 cup milk (decreased a tad), & 1/4 tsp. salt (cut in half). I allowed the milks & eggs to get to room temp before adding the cooled melted butter. I resisted the temptation to over mix & used butter flavor cooking spray on my griddle. We got a bakers dozen of the best moist & fluffy, slightly sweet & tangy pancakes ever! They were great without butter/syrup even! Yeah, it was a bit more work than my usual pancakes but not much more really & oh so worth the extra effort!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had good luck with this recipe but admitedly I tweaked it. We are whole grain people so my recipe was 2 1/2 cups of whole wheat flour with 1/2 cup of white unbleached, then I added 1/2 cup of extra buttermilk, 1/2 tsp raspberry flavor, 1/2 tsp almond flavor, and  I cup crushed raspberries. Then instead of adding the eggs all together I separated yolks from whites, beat the whites stiff, and I had the fluffiest pancakes. I find that separating egg yolks and whites like this always makes the fluffiest of pancakes, but it is the best solution for wholewheat and  essential for  buckwheat  pancakes or you could have a lump of lead in your stomach.

I made this recipe as written with the exception that I replaced the 1/2 cup milk with buttermilk.  The batter was so thin that it dripped!  I added close to 2 cups (all I had on hand) of my homemade pancake mix and it just thickened the batter enough that I could make pancakes.  The taste was wonderful with the addition of the pancake mix.  Because the recipe makes a lot, I will probably make them again, remembering to add the pancake mix.

text:
Did not change a thing about this recipe, it is perfect.  My pancakes were light and fluffy.  I added chocolate chips to some of mine and they were delicious!!  Made them for mother’s day and my mom one of the most pickiest eaters ever born loved them and made me make extra so she could have some for later.  If you are going to freeze them make sure the pancakes are nice and cooled off then wrap in plastic wrap.  To re-warm them defrost, preheat oven to 350 and bake for 10 minutes or until they are heated all the way through.  Make sure to place them in a single layer.  I will be making this recipe again and again.

OHMIGOSH!!!  These are the best ever!  Extremely light and fluffy!  (Anyone who doesn't get a light and fluffy pancake with this recipe is probably mixing them too long or too well.  The batter should be definitely lumpy.  Also be sure your baking powder still has its zing.)

These pancakes are an almost exact copy of the recipe I took years to come up with (so much for talent,:).  I use somewhat more sugar and no milk (when the batter is too stiff I use more buttermilk).  You will not go wrong following this great recipe exactly. Outstanding!  I made this exactly as the recipe stated.  The only things that I'd like to mention is that this made 15 large pancakes and I made them on a round electric griddle set at 375 degrees.  I also think it's important to let the milk, buttermilk, egg mixture come close to room temperature befor mixing with the dry ingredients.  I think this enhances the rise in the pancakes.  My entire family gave this 5 stars and I thank the original poster!

text:
Excellent recipe! Perfect pancake. Taste like something I ordered at my favorite local pancake joint but it's from my kitchen. Best advice I read and followed: don't over mix the batter, flour fruit or items prior to mixing with batter to keep them from sinking. Also, let wet mix items (eggs, buttermilk, milk) sit out at room temperature for an hour before use. We made blueberry and banana with pecan pancakes - so good! Enjoy!

text:
These are fantastic pancakes!  If you follow the pancake making tricks mentioned by others on here...do not overmix (there will still be some small clumps of flour here and there) and make sure all your ingredients are at room temperature before starting, you will end up with amazingly fluffy pancakes.  I'm not sure why so many complained about the amount the recipe makes...if you use the exact recipe and use 1/2 cup batter/pancake it makes 12 - 5 inch pancakes just like the recipe says.  For years I was in search of a pancake that matched a famous restaurant chain's and I've made many similar recipes, but all it really took was using a couple special techniques to get the desired result!

text:
This is the BEST pancake recipe EVER! We were living in Belize for a few months, and yes we are moving there permanently! Some things you can't leave behind. We found this recipe and added a few flares of our own.

First, in Belize we found someone who sells raw milk for about $1.50us per gallon...AWESOME! So we made REAL buttermilk by letting it set out and 'clabber'. This proved to be excellent in so many ways! Do a search on it, it opens the door to sooo many culinary options.

Second, I know that everyone says, 'Don't overmix', but I make sure to mix my batter THOROUGHLY, and I am always pleased. My pancakes turn out like fluffy pillows of heaven, and NEVER DRY! Especially with this recipe.

Make sure your butter is melted before adding to your mix, and make them BIG! I hate little pancakes that look like they were an accident...

text:
Perfect recipe just as is. The only thing I changed was the mixing order. I mixed the baking soda with the buttermilk instead of with the dry ingredients. I have found from my favorite scone recipe that does this, it makes for an even lighter, dough. The baking powder is added with the flour. I added the butter before the eggs so as not to cook the egg. thanks for a fantastic recipe.

text:
This recipe make pancakes that are as good as any I have ever eaten! I used whole milk followed the recipe and followed the recipe, except I used one cup of whole milk. Not because of knowledge or experience, but because I was not paying attention. They came out fantastic!

I paid close attention to the yeild since other reviewers mentioned it so often. I made 23 6-7" pancakes!

A few tips if I may.
Heat skillet to 375 degrees.
Do not overstir, small lumps are good!
Let the batter sit for 15 -20 minutes before cooking. The pancakes toward the end of my batch came out nicer than the first.

text:
2.25.12 ... https://www.allrecipes.com/recipe/24530/buttermilk-pancakes-ii/ ... I can't believe I haven't rated this!  'Was on a mission after trying so many average pancake recipes.  This is the BEST BUTTERMILK RECIPE EVER!  I've been trying, I know!  :D  Only suggestion is to warm the milk a little so the butter doesn't firm up when you add it.  It remelts, but I "feel" better having it smooth.  Full amount of butter is fabulous, but I only use 3T.  Fluffy Pancakes by Kris are really good nonbuttermilk pancakes, too. Note:  I only use 3T melted butter.  Entire isn't too much, just so much fat/  KK likes these better than fluffy, which are awesome, too.OUR WARM BLUEBERRY TOPPING: 1/4c sugar, 1T cornstarch, 1/8t cinnamon, pinch salt.  Bring to boil over medium till thickened.  Add 2t butter & 1pt blueberries.

text:
All I can say is "Wow"! These are the best pancakes I have ever made! Melt in your mouth good!
I also back up KLUGLE in agreeing that you will get excellent results if you allow your milk and eggs come to room temperature. The ingredients incorporate better - i.e. the melted butter doesn't "clump up" like it would if added to cold milk - a little kitchen science for you!

text:
I gave it 4 stars because I feel the batter was too thick and needed to be thinner.  I did use half whole wheat flour and half all purpose which gave them a denser consistency.  The flavor was delicious.  I did let the buttermilk, egg sit out until room temp, about 1 hour.  I used half butter and half home made lard, which I think gives better flavor and if they had been a bit thinner would have been out of this world, still good though.  I used the handy calculator to reduce recipe to 4 servings.

text:
This is almost exactly the recipe that I've been using for years from my standard Better Homes and Gardens cookbook.  the only difference is that the BHG recipe calls for 6 T. of vegetable oil instead of butter.  The butter makes it richer.  I find that it helps to let the finished batter sit for 5 minutes (about how long it takes to heat my griddle) before cooking the pancakes.  You can also add grated apples and cinnamon to the batter or blueberries or my kids' favorite: chocolate chips.  Great, easy standard recipe.  I'll never go back to using a store-bought mix again!

userID:
2485373
Display Name:
ZeroCreature
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1

12
favoritesCount:
43
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/215516.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These pancakes are delicious.  I wanted to just make a few pancakes, so I cut the recipe in 1/3, because most of the items are in increments of three.  However, some of the stuff is already in really small quantities, so I used common sense.  If you're interested in making about six to eight pancakes for one or two people here are the easy, rounded measurements for the 1/3 recipe:  A pinch of salt, 1.5 tablespoons of melted butter, and two tablespoons of milk.  HIGHLY recommend greasing your pan or griddle with bacon grease.  You won't need more than a teaspoon of it if you take a napkin and spread it around.  That way you're not adding a bunch of fat and cholesterol, but there IS a definite, subtle flavor and aroma difference.  I wanted to note that I used the thick-style (old fashioned, etc) buttermilk.  I'm pretty sure that that's what the person who wrote this recipe intended, because my pancakes were perfect.  If you're having issues with this recipe, try regular, thick buttermilk, not low fat.  You might have to hunt around, since low fat has become so DARNED ubiquitous, but it'll be worth the trouble.  Ironically, try looking at a health food store, like Sprouts or Whole Foods.  If you need something to do with the remainder of the buttermilk, may I suggest a homemade ranch dressing!  That's actually what I was hunting down my buttermilk for in the first place.  Tata everyone!  Great recipe!

text:
We made these pancakes for the first time today.  We followed the recipe exact and then towards the end of cooking, added some milk to thin the batter as it had become quite thick while setting.  We also added blueberries to some of the pancakes and they turned out great.  Definately better to use fresh buttermilk, but as other reviewers said-freeze your leftovers and microwave it next time you need it.  A definate must-melt the butter first and LET IT COOL...if yuou don't, you'll get chunky butter which cooled too fast, or worse-cooked eggs in the batter.

I've cooked plenty of recipes from this site, but this is the first one that has actually moved me to write a review.  These are by far the best pancakes I have ever had.  Delicious, flavorful, fluffy.  I followed another reviewer's suggestion of letting the liquid come to room temp before mixing with the dry ingredients, and only mixed them up enough to make sure I had no dry flour left.  Throw them on the griddle, add maple syrup, and enjoy heavenly pancakes.  I'll never make another kind again.

text:
Starting with the dry ingredients I dumped everything into my Waring blender, pulsed on low for 1 minute and starting pouring ¼ cup batter into my pre- heated Teflon egg pan. After cooking on side number 1 for about one minute  I sprinkled sliced blackberries on top and then flipped the cake to cook the other side.  OMG! These cakes were yummy. I ate mine covered in Maple syrup standing at the kitchen counter , feeding every other bite to my dog. He loved them as well.

text:
Although it needs light modification, this is a very good recipe. I adjusted it to serve 4. After mods it is: 1cup flour, 1cup buttermilk, 1 teaspoon each baking soda and powder, 1/4 teaspoon salt, 1/4 cup white sugar, 1 heaping tablespoon brown sugar, 4 tablespoons milk, 2 tablespoons real butter, 1 egg, 1/2 teaspoon vanilla.   They taste better than the pancakes we make at work(a local steakhouse that serves breakfast). They are so good the owner is concidering changing the recipe to my mod. Thanks to the uploader for the excellent starting point.

text:
These are a much requested breakfast in my house. They are perfect every time -light, fluffy and beautiful!  I've used powdered buttermilk (about 2c), I've used the substitute of 3 Tbsp white vinegar plus enough 2% milk to equal 3 cups (let sit about 5 minutes to sour) & of course good ol' buttermilk -all work great but obviously the real thing is best!  I usually use Splenda instead of sugar (double what the recipe calls for) and I add a tsp or two of vanilla.  I often make these just to freeze for the kids -I wrap each cooled pancake individually with plastic wrap and place them all in gallon freezer bags.  They are a quick, tasty breakfast defrosted in the microwave (the toaster dries them out too much) served with Brown & Serve Sausage Links and fresh fruit!  Baby #3 is on the way any day now so I'm working on a large batch right now to freeze so I'll have a few easy breakfasts when we return from the hospital!  I'd give these 10 stars if I could!  One batch makes about 32 (3 inch) pancakes which I make using a 1/4 measuring cup.

text:
This recipe is by far the best I've ever made or tried! For fluffier pancakes, here's a few tips: 1)Warm the eggs to at least room temp; 2)warm the milk and buttermilk to a little warmer than room temp; 3)add the eggs, milk and buttermilk in one bowl and beat lightly to mix; 4) when adding to the flour mixture, beat gently with a whisk just until it's incorporated, then mix gently until it's still somewhat lumpy. These were over an inch thick, fluffy and delicious!

text:
Unbelievable! This recipe was very easy to make and to be honest - I've never had pancakes this good - especially ones that I made from scratch! We won't bother with the boxes anymore. This recipe is unbeatable! I did add vanilla and cinnamon for a bit of a kick. Also - resist the urge to try and spread your batter out to make thinner pancakes - these are WAY better nice a fluffy. They do take longer to cook than your typical box pancake though - so be patient! Thanks for an awesome recipe - to everyone else - ENJOY!
****REVIEW UPDATE****
Just thought I'd add a bit more to my previous review - after rediscovering this recipe (can't believe I ever forgot it!) my family has fallen head over heels for it again. Two tips to add though - first - if you don't have buttermilk, just sour your milk with lemon juice - put about 2 TBS lemon juice in your measuring pitcher and then add milk to make up your 3 cups let sit while you prep your other ingredients and voila! you have buttermilk. I think that's why I "forgot" about the recipe because I never have buttermilk on hand - doing it this way makes the pancakes every bit as good and you don't have to worry about having buttermilk if you don't usually buy it. The other tip is these pancakes freeze amazingly well! I now make a huge batch every Saturday and then freeze what we don't eat - pop them in the toaster during the week and they almost seem to taste better - crispy on the outside and light and fluffy on the inside. My husband like

text:
Edit: on my second making of the recipe I cut out all of the sugar and added a tsp and a half of real vanilla essence. It's even better and more delicious!

I halved the servings (to 6) and also halved the amount of sugar. Because the recipe then called for 1 1/2 eggs I just used 1 egg. It came out perfectly. At first I thought there was far too much batter for three people. But, using 1/2 cup per pancake it make 6 perfect equal size pancakes. It was brill! My guest thoroughly enjoyed them and wolfed them down.

I also had 1/2 cup less buttermilk than was required so I was forced to add another 1/2 cup non-fat milk. Worked like a charm.

These will be my standard buttermilk pancakes now. Thanks!

text:
Without a doubt, the best pancakes I've ever made, and I've tried many!  I did add a little vanilla, but that's our personal taste.  These freeze beautifully and go from freezer to toaster to table with no problem.  Simply place them in single layers between sheets of parchment or waxed paper, put them on a cookie sheet and freeze.  After they're frozen, remove from the cookie sheet and place in ziploc bags, then remove and toast as needed.  Perfection!  Thanks for a great recipe that we'll use again and again!

userID:
1355620
Display Name:
Yuki

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Don't try too hard to not overmix - I did on my first try, and I had LARGE clumps and the pancake had blotches of white dry mix! It was also quite bland, even after adding 1tsp vanilla to 1/3 of the batch. I still don't know what I did wrong and I was going to rate this recipe badly, but decided to try again. This time, I followed the advices and beat the egg whites separately and folded it into the batter AFTER mixing the dry/wet parts, and let it sit overnight - this morning (Mother's day), I heat the pan up until a few drops of water took 7-8 seconds to evaporate, and cooked the pancakes a little less than 2min each side without oil. They turned out to be light, fluffy and actually had some (eggy) taste! Do NOT overcook, the least bit of overcooking will hide the taste of the pancakes! Also, to get it crisp, undercook it slightly and toast them briefly in the oven/toaster. My mom even asked me where I bought the pancakes!

text:
I wasn't sure just what the fresh buttermilk meant. We used to churn our buttermilk when I grew up on the farm. I wasn't about to try that again so I used buttermilk from the supermarket. I made the recipe using all the ingridents listed except only about half 1/2 tbs sugar. I did seperate the eggs and beat the whites until fluffy and folded into the wet mixture (cause that's what my wife does when she makes her wonderful pancakes). I thought that my pancakes were every bit as tasty and fluffy as hers... and that's saying a LOT! VERY fluffy and VERY tasty! I've fixed these with and without beating the egg whites and beating the egg whites make them even more fluffy! If you don't like these, you've done something wrong!

The only thing that may be different is I noticed my buttermilk is 'fat free' not sure if that makes any difference at all, but they are so good! I don't understand anyone not thinking these are good. The recipe does make a TON of batter. I am going to try to freeze the actual pancakes and see if they are as good as everyone says after being frozen and microwaved. Definitely a keeper for us. My 9 year old son just ate 4 and is asking for more. Thank you for this great recipe!

text:
This is the only recipe for pancakes that I use. They are easy to make and the have superb taste. Anyone who gives less than 4 stars on these either doesn't know how to cook, or doesn't know what truly delicious pancakes taste like. Let your buttermilk and milk sit out for an hour to get to room temperature. This ensures FLUFFY cakes. Follow the simple steps, and enjoy. I use a quick shot of oil instead of melted margarine, but sometimes leave it out since I oil up the cast iron skillet really well. Cast iron will give you excellent results.

text:
These are so delicious! Definitely allow the eggs milk and buttermilk to come to room temperature. I also sifted all my dry ingredients and made a well in the center to pour and mix my wet ingredients. These are just like the "good old fashioned" pancakes, except they use buttermilk. This gives them an even richer, more buttery taste. One last tip, I let the batter set for about ten minutes while I fry up my bacon on my griddle. I then use an old (clean!) ketchup bottle to dispense the batter. Five stars!!!!

This is my go-to pancake recipe, and I have found no others that compare. I've just started halving the recipe in an effort to have my family consume less (you know, calories...) and it worked just fine. This recipe is fantastic with add-ins-- my favorite so far has been with bananas.

country:
None
text:
This recipe makes some of the best pancakes I've ever had, and I worked in a diner for several years that was known for breakfast.  The only thing I've changed is the author's recommendation to leave the mixing until just before cooking.  If you let the batter sit for about 10-15 minutes before cooking, that baking soda really goes to work and the batter starts to expand.  This makes for super pillowy pancakes.  It's like eating buttery clouds.

country:
None
text:
I have made these pancakes MANY times by now, and they are a consistent hit with my family.  I read a few of the negative reviews because I was curious.  Some reviewers are having problems with lumps of butter in the batter.  When I am putting together the wet ingredients, I melt the butter first thing.  I whisk together the eggs, milk, and buttermilk.  Then I SLOWLY drizzle in the butter, whisking it in as I go.  This makes for a nice smooth batter without the lumps of butter.

userID:
922931
Display Name:
BOXRDAWGZ
isPro:
False

4

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3055.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Perfect recipe. I added 1 addtl TBSP of sugar and nothing more.  As others have stated you do not want to over mix this recipe. When you put dry into wet, mix slowly 4-6 folds until you see it's incorporated. It should be lumpy and almost like a beginning paper mache mix. I was able to make 10-12 Texas size pancakes.  I cook for 30 seconds on each side over low.  You know the pancake is ready to flip when all sides are slightly bubbling. I have added fresh blueberries which takes the recipe to a whole different yum factor.  I pour the mix in the pan and immediately add fresh blueberries to the uncooked side. Once the pancake is flipped it seals in the berries. I fed myself, son, daughter, mother and hubby with this recipe.  It has been my go to for years.  If the recipe is not turning out, it is not the recipe, it is an error on the preparers end. My first time I over mixed and they did not rise and were limp cakes, nothing special. Over mixing is the #1 cause of this recipe failure.  I have never used room temp items as my family loves to eat not wait...lol   They always rise beautiful thankfully.  I have found not to mix this recipe until I begin making them as the pancakes tend not to come out as well if I premix. Someday I will freeze and try that as others have had success. This recipe takes time, but it is worth the little effort. TY for sharing a simple but delicious recipe!

text:
This was easy and yummy.  I mixed the liquid ingredients in the blender to make them fluffy. It was forgiving in that I didn't have enough buttermilk so I added extra milk and a little less flour and they still turned out fluffy and good. I added blueberries which was a nice addition but these were very good even without them. I will definitely make these again. Note: you can keep buttermilk for a very long time: As you use it, add more milk and let it ferment for a day out of the fridge or for a week inside and one carton will make 3 or 4 cartons.

text:
This is from someone who only made pancakes once before (from a premade mix) and burned them.  This was a fantastic recipe.  The buttermilk adds a dense feel that you get from the mega pancakes at breakfast restaurants.  As long as you don't stir the batter too much, they turn out fluffy as well.  Can't stress enough how important it is to leave those flour clumps in.  I left the buttermilk, eggs, and milk sitting out for 40 minutes like another reviewer suggested, which worked well.

city:

country:
None
text:
I had some leftover buttermilk from making red velvet cupcakes, so I thought I'd give this recipe a shot. WOW. These were some amazing pancakes. I added 3 large overripe bananas that I also had sitting around (maybe about 1 to 1.5 cups mashed), and they were amazing! I ate one for dessert, and the rest of the pancakes are going in the freezer for later as another reviewer suggested. You could easily add blueberries or chocolate chips in place of the bananas if you want to change the flavor. I waited until I mixed the wet/dry ingredients together to add in the mashed bananas. I also didn't beat the wet ingredients (just whisked them together because I was too lazy to get out the mixer and beaters), and I cooked over low/medium heat instead of medium/high ... not sure if it's my electric stove top or the bananas or what, but medium/high nearly burnt the first pancake. Thank you for this recipe! Will definitely be making again!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had leftover buttermilk in the fridge, and have a family who loves pancakes.  By unamimous vote, these were the best pancakes I've ever made. The batter was amazingly light and fluffy and so were the pancakes.  Melt in your mouth fluffy!  I whipped the eggs before adding them to the milk and used a 1/4 tsp of vanilla.  Caution not to overstir when combining wet to dry and to keep stirring when adding hot butter to wet as not to "scramble" the eggs.   This recipe makes A LOT of batter and 1/2 cup batter pancakes was too much.  It was difficult to get them to cook through in the middle with out getting them too dark.  Next time I will 1/2 the recipe and use 1/3 cup portions.  This is my "go to" pancake recipe now!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I found the best way to make the pancakes extra fluffy!  Fill the sink with hot water right from the tap and set the bowl with the wet mixture in the sink so the hot water warms them up.  Let sit for 15-20 min.  The idea is that the warmer the wet mixture is; the better the reaction with the baking soda and powder.  So warmer then room temperature is good.  We just don't want to cook the eggs and hot tap water is not hot enough for that anyway.  And a teaspoon and a half of vanilla is a god idea too.

text:
This turned out to be an average recipe for me.  I found it to be kind of acidic.  I made a 2/3 recipe, and added bananas and chocolate chips to them.  They were okay, and puffed up, but I would not consider them fluffy. Too much moisture for me.  I agree with another reviewer that a pancake should have a little crunch on the outside and cake-like on the inside.  This wasn't very cake-like.  I just thought it wasn't chemically balanced.  My daughter and husband didn't notice, and scarfed them up.  But I'm a texture-phile with my baked goods, and I thought it was off.

text:
These are really good! I would give it 4.5 stars if possible. Taste like restaurant pancakes! The buttermilk is a must, it cannot be substituted for milk + Vinegar. The right texture can only be attained from the real thing. Use unsalted butter or cut the salt from the main recipe. And no maple syrup tastes as good as the real thing in my opinion but thats up to you....also would be good with a fruit syrup.Watch them close because they can burn very fast because of the sugar in the batter.

text:
These pancakes are delicous! I was expecting them to be a bit bigger and fluffier, but they were delicious and worth five stars all the same! I usually just use a pancake box mix for big breakfasts, but this was well-worth trying. I cooked up some bacon, sliced it into 1-inch pieces, coated the pieces and some cheddar cheese with flour, and mixed into this pancake batter. Makes very delicious bacon-cheddar pancakes! But I also made some plain and some with chocolate chip, all super delicious! It made a ton of pancakes, way more than the recipe says, but that was definitely okay with my husband and I, they were so good!
Update: I made these pancakes again for my mom-in-law, and they were huge and fluffy, as promised! My baking powder must have been too old before. Super delicious, give them a try!

I made the recipe, scaled for 4 pancakes, exactly as written with the exception that I used homemade kefir milk instead of buttermilk (a normal substitute for me, and since it's just soured milk it should not be considered a fundamental change). It came out exactly as advertised - light and fluffy and delicious.  Using the 4-pancake recipe and adding 4 oz of fresh blueberries the batter, I got 8 pancakes, 5" wide and 1/2" or better thick.  I don't understand why some cooks didn't have them rise enough, but I was using fairly new baking soda and that would help I guess.  I could actually see them rise on the griddle as they cooked.  I think the recipe might be even better with a tad of cinnamon, and I might try using spelt flour; but these would be for my own taste and I think the recipe is excellent as it is written.  Thank you for posting it!


         Update:  I made the recipe again with a mod.  Using the recipe scaled to 4 pancake size, you would add 3/4 tsp ground cinnamon to the dry ingredients and 1 tsp vanilla extract to the wet ingredients before mixing them together.  I must say, the extra flavoring took it from excellent to somewhere near outrageous.

text:
I'm new to the cooking world, especially from scratch, so when got the ingredients I bought the wrong baking soda.  The morning I made these pancakes I decided to leave it out, thinking it would not make a difference.  Was I wrong, 100% wrong. The taste was sour and bitter.  So, instead of throwing away the rest of the batter I went and got the baking soda that's intended for cooking.  What a difference 1 1/2 tspns makes.  The only difference I want to change next time I make these awesome pancakes is to scale down the servings.  Thanks for sharing these great tasting pancakes.

text:
These are my favorite pancakes.  I've made them many times and each time they come out perfectly.  Its best if you follow the recipe exactly, and use fresh buttermilk.  Top them with a little butter, and maybe just a touch of real maple syrup.  Drenching them in anything else wouldn't do it justice!  I've 1/4'd, 1/3'd, 1/2'd and doubled the recipe depending on how many people are eating, and each time they are perfect.  You really can only eat about 2 pancakes per person... they are big and filling!

text:
These pancakes were PERFECT! Fluffy, with just the right amount of salt...I didn't even need butter, just syrup! I scaled it down to 4 servings and that made 7 good sized pancakes...I was going to beat egg white seperately to soft peaks, and then add it at the end for extra fluff, but i decided not to, and turns out these pancakes didn't need the extra help =) I added a little vanilla (1 tsp) and a few shakes of cinnamon along with some blueberries (lightly coated in flour so they don't sink to the bottom =) for the second batch and those were fantastic as well. This will definately be my go to pancake recipe!

text:
These are super yummy. They're AWESOME made with buttermilk, still good made with "fake buttermilk" (milk + vinegar or milk + lemon juice). But if you can get the buttermilk, it's definitely better. I usually use half whole wheat flour. I make up "mixes" by measuring the dry ingredients into a ziploc, and write on it the wet ingredients to add. Makes it quicker to make in the mornings (I'm not a morning person so having the "mix" helps me.) UPDATE: I now do 2/3 whole wheat (2 cups ww, 1 cup white). I also add a handful of old fashioned oats (probably 1/3 cup). They're delicious and healthy.

text:
We received a griddle for our wedding last year and I had never used it until I found this recipe.  This recipe was delicious.  The only thing I changed about this recipe was that I added 1 tsp of vanilla.  Everything else about this recipe is right on.  My hubby said, "these are the best pancakes you've ever made." At first I wasn't sure about doing the original amount but after reading several reviews I decided that since we are on a 4 day weekend it would be nice to have fresh pancakes everyday.  So far we are on day 2 and we still have enough batter for one more day.  Don't worry nothing will happen to it.  I used to work at a restaurant at the "Happiest Place on Earth" and we always refrigerated left over batter.  So far I've made chocolate chip pancakes and blueberry ones to add more bang to them but my hubby prefers them plain.  This recipe is great. I really suggest you try it. Like previous reviewers suggestions I get the griddle at 350 degrees.

UPDATE: I love these pancakes. I'll never go back to any other ones. I've made them on several occasions.

text:
I've made a few buttermilk receipes from  scratch, and this is by far my favorite!  I've had to cut the receipe down  to 1/3 of the ingredients. Doing so has given me approx. 6 medium sized pancakes -- enough for  two.  I've made it several times already and tweeked it a bit, and played with a few variations.  I added real 1tsp vanilla and 2 tsps of sugar.  I've also substituted vanilla creamer instead of  milk.  I ran out of buttermilk one morning and ended up using lowfat eggnog. Absolutely delicious! The pancakes are very moist and full of flavor.

text:
I gave it 5 stars despite 2 changes I made.  I used only 1/3 of the recipe as there are only 4 of us in the house, two of whom are 5 or under.  I saw 3 cups of flour and buttermilk and knew that it would be overkill.  The 1/3 of a batch made six ~5" pancakes.  The other change I made was using fresh milled flour.  I used 1/2 cup of hard white wheat, and 1/2 cup of soft white wheat.  It turned out wonderfully.  I'll be adding this to my recipe box for later use.  :)

text:
PERFECT Pancakes.  I respectfully do not know how anyone could disagree.  I have searched for the pancakes they make at Grand Lux Cafe in Las Vegas - these are the ones!  I got beautifully colored, light, spongey pancakes.  These are no extra effort or time than any other pancake recipe - very easy.  Beware, the recipe makes alot but I kept mine in the fridge for 3 days (making pancakes each day) and my batter kept its integrity just fine.  Excellent recipe - thank you!
*Remember what Alton Brown of Food TV says:  Do not over mix!  Fold batter about 15 times and walk away.  Let it sit a minute (or an hour in the fridge)to let the dry absorb more of the wet.
You will get light, spongey pancakes.
Actual buttermilk is KEY!

userID:
2452999
Display Name:
Naryia
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/101205.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe has changed how I feel about pancakes! I replaced 2 cups of the AP flour with 2 cups of whole spelt and the remaining cup for 1 Cup of Quinoa (pronounced keen-wah) flour (organic Bob's Red Mill). It's amazing what an earthy nutty flavor the quinoa adds, and still remains light and fluffy, not to mention very healthy. I have had it both ways and feel the spelt and quinoa is better than AP. I also used someone's tip for letting the milk and eggs come to room temp to help keep things fluffy. Though usually I find it just takes too long for the milk to hit room temp which in turn makes the melted butter flake up and not distribute properly in the whole batter. To combat this I have begun to take my melted butter and slowly beat it into my eggs before adding to the milks. The liquid fats of the yolks join to the butter fats and keep them from flaking up when added to the cooler milks. This should take you around 1 minute to do, at a slow pour, constantly beating the egg so it doesn't scramble. Cook these no higher than 300 degrees F, otherwise the insides don't get done in time for the outsides. And don't over-stir! Leave lumps in the batter, they will cook out just fine.

text:
I will forever be plagued with making these dang pancakes!  My boyfriend loves them, and whines for me to make them constantly!  We've tried whole wheat flour and blueberry variations, and they turn out just as well.  I always omit the added sugar and REAL maple syrup is a must!!  **UPDATED** I'm on about batch 100 of these pancakes and I thought I'd add to my review.  When making these, sometimes we use half whole wheat and half white flour.  We cook in a cast iron skillet on medium to medium-low heat (don't have your heat too high!) and add a thin layer of vegetable oil before each batch.  When the topside of the pancake becomes dull and forms air-bubbles, that's when you flip them.  If your pancake is too dark when this happens, turn down your heat.  We freeze leftovers in packs of four (they break apart easily, so no need to separate with anything), and pop them in the toaster in the mornings before school.  This recipe is now our 'always' pancake recipe.  Enjoy!

text:
I thought this was an excellent pancake recipe! I followed others' advice by letting my buttermilk/milk sit out for a little while before adding the eggs and mixing it with the dry ingredients, and the pancakes were very fluffy and delicious. I also added a splash of vanilla and substitued 1/4 c. wheat germ for about 1/4 c of flour. I found the batter to be a bit thick, but just added some more milk to thin a bit (may be because of my wheat germ), and be warned that this makes at least a dozen huge pancakes--it fed 3 adults and 2 toddlers with less than half the batter. But hey, I just put the batter in the fridge and we'll have more pancakes tomorrow! YUMMMY!

text:
The absolute best pancakes I've ever made.  The texture was exactly what I was looking for, almost yeasty.  They were so light and fluffy, even my husband commented that they were the best pancakes he'd ever tasted!  I did add about 1 tbls of pure vanilla as others suggested but otherwise followed the recipe exactly.  I used a rubber spatula to stir in the wet ingredients and it worked perfectly as I could easily scrape down the sides of the large bowl while mixing.  I too was surprised at how the lumpy batter turned out the smoothest, lightest pancakes ever!  Be sure to use all the ingredients as listed, no substitutions.  It makes LOTS of pancakes so I freeze the left overs and microwave for 1 to 1 1/2 minutes for 3 pancakes.

country:
None
text:
okay...these pancakes were incredible tasting!  They really were good...but just a few comments
1. the batter was way thick (not at all runny even by following the recipe exactly). I actually needed to add more milk!
2.) one reader suggested that you freeze the extras for toaster pancakes another day.  The problem is these pancakes rise quite a bit so putting the pancakes in the toaster will toast the outside (which will smell and taste great) but the center of the pancake will be rock hard as it is still frozen.  
Definitely half this recipe or cook when you have lots of people over.  Thanks for the recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been using this recipe for months now - I will no longer be buying Bisquick!  I usually halve the recipe and I make my own buttermilk by adding  1 T. cider vinegar per 1 c. milk (do this first thing to let it set for about 5 minutes before adding the rest of the ingredients).  I also always sift the dry ingredients.  To make blueberry pancakes, I do not add the blueberries to the batter (or it turns everything purple)- instead I pour the batter onto the griddle and then I drop the [still frozen] blueberries onto the pancake itself.  I get the mini, organic blueberries from Trader Joe's.  It takes a touch longer when adding the blueberries as they're still frozen but it's quite delicious.  We serve the blueberry pancakes with whipped cream and the regular ones with real maple syrup.  Not only do my husband and I love these pancakes, my 10 month old son cannot get enough!  (And of course the baby gets his sans topping!)

text:
Our family loves these pancakes.  I haven't used a mix since trying this recipe. They are nice and fluffy. I do sometimes add a little vanilla. I once tried using the powered buttermilk instead of fresh and was disappointed with the result.  I do have a tip:  The melted butter will not resolidify if you mix it with the egg yolks.  I just separate the eggs, and pour the melted butter into the yolks and whisk.  No more butter lumps in the batter.

text:
definitely a keeper! these made the biggest, fluffiest, tastiest pancakes I've ever had. I made mine 8 inches across and they still turned out great. the buttermilk really makes it special. and fyi, the intro to this recipe says "fresh buttermilk" but you don't need to go out and buy some if you usually don't. just add a tablespoon of lemon juice to a cup of milk, let it sit until it gets lumpy. voila.

text:
Yes, I cut this recipe by two thirds, otherwise this recipe would make enough pancakes to feed my whole neighborhood.  I've used these same ingredients for years and have made few alterations except sometimes I add some vanilla flavoring.  This recipe makes wonderful light pancakes, buttermilk seems to make a vast difference.  If you don't sit the mixed batter aside for a few minutes and let the baking powder do it's thing, your pancakes will not be light and fluffy.

country:
None
text:
Best pancakes!  My husband is not a pancake kind of guy. In fact, he's not a breakfast guy, except for bacon. The world is right if there's bacon. So, I made these for me and the kiddos. He tasted one of theirs and couldn't stop raving. I made them exactly according to the recipe with just two minor changes. I used all buttermilk, no plain milk, and I added 1 tsp vanilla and 1 tsp almond extract. That's it, and I'm sure that didn't put them over the top. I cannot over emphasize the part about overstirring.  Stir the dry ingredients well, but then basically just ensure the dry ingredients get wet with the well-mixed egg mixture.  You'll get thick and fluffy mouth watering pancakes, ones that even a bacon-for-breakfast guy wants to eat.

Please, I beg of you, ignore the negative comments on this post! These are some of the best pancakes I've ever had. The only thing I did different was add a splash of vanilla and topped with blueberry sauce and whipped cream. Make it exactly as the directions specify. Have your ingredients room temperature and make sure not to over mix. I cooked the batter on my griddle which I greased down with shortning. I was able to make 28 pancakes. Delicious!!

text:
Awesome pancakes!  I've done this with true buttermilk and "homemade buttermilk", i.e. sour milk (1 tbsp cider vinegar per 1 cup milk) and both ways turn out great.  Obviously better with true buttermilk but works in a pinch.  I also tried adding a bit of fresh ground nutmeg and that was amazing, too.  Quite simply, you can't go wrong with these pancakes.  Just don't over stir!

text:
I have forever changed my opinion of scratch vs convenience. My family LOVED this recipe. It has just the right amount of fluffiness and a slight crunch on the outsides.  The flavor was perfect. Not too sweet, not dry at all, not too buttery.  You do need to eat them right away though.   You lose some of the value when you lose the crunch.  Awesome recipe!  Thanks so much!  Btw, goes great with the homemade blueberry syrup I made too!

My husband likes a pancake breakfast every Sunday. I usually just make the box mix type for him. We have tried two different brands. This Sunday I just happened to be out of mix so I googled pancake recipes and found this one. It is easy to make and makes a ton of batter. I am not big on pancakes but WOW! I have to say this is one of the best tasting pancake recipes I have tasted! This will be my go to every Sunday!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Everyone loved this recipe.  My husband (53yo) gave the highest compliment (which he doesn't give easily), that these were the best pancakes he's ever had.  I don't think I've ever heard him say this about anything.  I will say that I used White Lily self-rising flour and omitted the baking powder and salt.  If you're in the south and it is available to you, White Lily makes a huge difference with baked goods.  Not sure how it is, but there really is a difference.  America's Test Kitchens seems to think so, too, which convinced me.  Oh, and you must use buttermilk.  Regular milk will make it too watery.  If you don't have buttermilk, make a different recipe.

This was an amazing recipe.  I didn't change a thing.  The pancakes were light and fluffy with an incredible amount of flavor.  I've never made buttermilk pancakes before but I can guarantee I will again.  The best part is that it was two adults, and one very picky autistic child. text:
I really like these pancakes! I modified the recipe just a tad: I added 1/2 tsp vanilla and was generous with the sugar (my 3 tablespoons were probably more like 4). Other than that I made the recipe as is, with the amounts called for. It made about 14 pancakes. I had 7 left over, so I froze them with a piece of parchment paper in between the individual pancakes, and they were great microwaved. This will be my go-to pancake recipe from now on. Soooo much better than boxed pancake mix!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Thank you so much for this recipe!  I use this recipe for pancakes and belgian waffles; my kids ask for these pancakes every single day.  If I have the time, I let the buttermilk, eggs and milk sit out for 1/2 hour or more to get to room temp.  I also try to melt the butter at least 15 minutes before I need it, or use ghee, to avoid having the butter solidify in the liquids and/or cook the eggs.  The recipe definitely makes a huge amount.  If I want just enough for one brunch, I make a third of the recipe.  It is definitely best right after combining the wet/dry ingredients, but does sit well and I often make an entire recipe on Sunday and use it throughout the week.  Waffles I've made with this batter also freeze and reheat really well in the toaster.

I just made these for our Thanksgiving Breakfast. They are delicious! Even my husband, who is not a huge breakfast fan, loved these. I did add an extra tablespoon of sugar and 1 teaspoon of vanilla. This is the best pancake recipe I have made. They were easy to make too. Just remember to not over mix the batter ~ the lumps mean light and fluffy pancakes. This batter will make an abundance of pancakes. I think it is safe to say you could easily feed eight people with this recipe.

These were so fluffy!!!! I didn't have any buttermilk on hand and I was hungry, my wife had taken the car to work and since we only have one car I couldn't go buy buttermilk.  Luckily, I had some cold breast milk my wife had pumped for our daughter so I used that in place of the buttermilk and they turned out great!  At first my wife was mad that I used her milk in pancakes instead of giving it to our daughter but I let her taste how delicious and fluffy they were and she soon forgot all about it!  Plus I reminded her that she makes so much that we still have 1 month supply in the freezer and she agreed that I made the right call!

text:
Made them for the first time this morning.  Added 1 and 1/2 tsp vanilla and juice from 1/2 lemon.  Let the liquid portion sit at room temperature for about an hour and a half.  Had to warm slightly in the microwave before mixing because the butter congealed when initially mixed with the cold milk.  Once warm, butter remelted and the pancakes turned out perfect.  Made batches of blueberry, chocolate chip and banana pancakes.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
These turned out very well. I followed the recipe to the letter. I don't use buttermilk often, so I keep frozen cubes of it and thaw when needed. I melted the buttermilk cubes and butter together, then added the milk and egg to them. When I combined this with the dry ingredients I was quite surprised how fluffy the batter was. I'm guessing that cold milk & buttermilk is the reason why others aren't getting the fluff factor.

These pancakes turned out great, and the only reason I can't give a 5 star is because there's a cafe in town that trumps these. I don't know what their secret is, but I'll share if I ever find out. In the meantime, when making your own, these are quite good. I will definitely make them again.

text:
Adjust the recipe down to 4 servings and you get the perfect amount of pancakes for 2! It keeps the nice ratio of ingredients that makes this recipe easy and delicious. Also remember to make more of your own buttermilk (add milk to buttermilk in a mason jar, cover and let sit at room temp for 24 hours, then  refrigerate) to use for future enjoyment of these great hotcakes!

text:
Nice fluffy pancakes. I made them the night before and refrigerated and then let the batter sit at room temp before frying for a 1//2 hr. Do not stir batter before frying. I used a 1/4 c. for each pancake.  I put blueberries on 1/2 of the pancakes when frying. I sprinkled a little sugar over the blueberries before adding. Another favorite recipe on Allrecipes. The batter keeps well for several days.

text:
The first time I made these I followed the recipe as so, and the batter turned out super watery, so my pancakes came out super thin, so the next time I made them I made a few changes, I used a little bit less buttermilk than the recipe called for and I didnt use milk, so my batter turned up less watery. But overall the pancakes tasted really good, they werent sweet like the boxed kind which I really liked, so I will be definiteley making these again!!

text:
This is the best buttermilk pancake recipe...EVER! I have made it lots of times and love it.  Then on a trip to Minneapolis, we ate at a breakfast place called Fat Nat's.  They are famous for their omelets and pancakes.  Their pancakes had a slight almond flavor, so now I add 1/2 teaspoon of almond flavoring.  They don't taste "almondy", but your taste buds pick another layer of flavor. The batter should be quite lumpy to get the lightest, fluffiest pancakes. My family absolutely loves them.

This is a keeper!  I was raised in a pineapple plantation town in the 1960's and as a child my parents used to send me to the restaurant to pick up a box of cooked pancakes, and as a result, became the benchmark for which I judged all other pancakes.  The lady who used to scratch make those pancakes had long since past but my search for a replacement/recipe went on for well over 40 years and I feel that this is the "one!"  Cooked it for the first time the other day and me, my wife & kids just loved it...moist, fluffy, ono (delicous)...what else can I say?  Try it, you'll like it!

For a fun kid-friendly twist, slice bananas into discs and dunk them in batter and cook on the griddle - you'll get perfectly round little fruit-filled pancakes that are great for snacks as well as breakfast (the banana gets a sweet pudding-like consistency) -  make a bunch and reheat in toaster oven

text:
Excellent recipe. Regarding the serving sizes - I scaled back by 1/3, and still produced 15 5" pancakes. So beware of quantities. I also had to add a bit more milk (1/4 cup of so) after I mixed everything, because the mixture was a bit too thick and didn't spread evenly on the skillet. But that always differs based on flour quality. Thanks!

text:
These were super easy to make, and my husband says they are the best pancakes I have EVER made for him.  I have been cooking a LONG time, am a Southern cook, and this is the most moist, light and fluffy pancake ever - melts in your mouth!  And I did not pay special attention to waiting until the end to mix it together - I mixed all the dry ingredients and added the wet ones to it, stirred it up good, then made sure my griddle was good and hot, and these only needed about 15 seconds per side to cook and were perfect!  This will be my only pancake recipe from now on!

I don't  even like pancakes-and I thought these were delicious! But, being a non-pancake fan, I had to ask my son, the pancake "connoisseur" who proclaimed "these are good" (Finally! he has never liked any of my recipes ;) I did follow the recipe, however I thinned the batter with a couple Tbsp milk. I noticed the first half of the batter were a bit fluffier than the latter half-but regardless they all turned out great. (I split the recipe in half; I beat the three eggs and took half of that for the recipe since I did not need so many. Half a recipe made about 9 (5-inch) pancakes. I'll be saving this one! Thanks!

text:
Perfect! I added a teaspoon of pure vanilla extract because that just adds so much flavor. Today I made this with "caramelized" banana slices. Just melt butter in the pan, place sliced bananas on the grill for a minute, then pour the batter over. When you flip your pancake, the bananas will be a golden caramel. 

FYI...I have made every recipe for pancakes on this site that called for buttermilk or sour cream. This one is the best.

Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2011-09-04T02:10:15.73
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
1283046
Display Name:
DAYR
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
12
favoritesCount:
28
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/323435.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
had some buttermilk to use up. last batch of buttermilk pancakes i made (recipe from the buttermilk box!) were really THICK and dense, not my type of pancake. 
I cut down the amounts to 1/3 = 1 cup flour, 1 tbs sugar etc etc, came up with 1/6 up of milk (v hard to measure).
I followed the instructions properly - combined the batter at the last minute, and only until just mixed, quite lumpy looking batter, the lumps were air bubbles and lumps of flour (like the other user said). Also, my butter happened to be contaminated with cinnamon powder (left over frm some muffins) so i added a few dashes of cinnamon powder (about 1 teaspoon) and one teaspoon vanilla bean paste.
First pancake was SUPER THICK so I added another 1/6 cup of milk (2x the recipe amount) - i had accidentally poured out too much anyway. Batter became quite abit more liquid and pancake turned out lighter and fluffier. 
Quite yummy, and easy to eat. I made mine quite thin, not crepe thinness, but thinner than your average hotcake. Also re-heated them (they cooled very fast) on the pan so they had very slightly crisp outside layer :)
Thank you for sharing!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

userID:
3182935
Display Name:
Deborah Glasbrener Marriott
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7739391.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I finally had to rate this recipe.  I have made it probably 100 times.  It is an awesome basic recipe and is very easy to cusomize.  I think it is very important to use real buttermilk.  The powdered buttermilk changes the texture and is too thin.  I use a whole container of buttermilk (4 cups) and adjust all of my other ingredients proportionally (4 T sugar, 4 t baking powder, 4 eggs, etc.).  It makes a lot, then I freeze the leftover pancakes (they freeze well...then just pop them in the toaster or microwave).  I adjust the thickness of the mixture by adjusting the milk.  Then let your imagination run wild... orange zest & strawberries; chopped apples and walnuts; peaches and almonds; mini chocolate chips for the kids; strawberries, bananas, choc chips and whipped creme on holidays; raspberries; blueberries and orange zest ... you get the idea.  My kids will no longer choke down a box mix pancake (even when we are camping)!  Oh ... and don't forget the real syrup!

text:
My boys LOVE this!  Regular Bisquick pancakes will no longer do in our house.  I've made this a zillion times now, with chocolate chips, pecans, apples, peaches, and more.  The only thing I do is ease up on the amount of butter.  They get a little heavy and flat if I use the amount of butter called for.  This may be because I always scale the recipe back for 6 pancakes, and maybe in scaling the ratio gets messed up.  But, I would recommend this recipe to anyone for great restaurant-quality pancakes!  Thank you!!

text:
This has become our "go to" pancake recipe.   We usually add a splash of vanilla, as my hubs and daughter love vanilla.   Very easy to adjust the serving sizes as long as you remember to make it divisible  by 4.  We like over-sized pancakes and usually get 2.5 servings out of the 4 serving recipe
Update -I was on my own for breakfast so I added a dash of cinnamon and some toasted and chopped pecans...took it to the next level of awesomeness!

text:
We had a pancake cook-off at church tonight and we SMOKED everybody with this recipe!  I added (floured) butterscotch chips to the batter, cinnamon sugar apples, caramel syrup (just regular syrup mixed with butterscotch-caramel ice cream topping) and whipped cream to the top.    It was definitely a sweet, dessert-type pancake, but boy was it GOOOOOD!  So light and fluffy!  Make sure to cook them up right away!  The longer the batter sits the less fluffy they were.

text:
I gave it 3 starts just for following the recipe exactly and it was just ok, nothing to rave about. I think needs more sugar and vanilla. BUT I give 5 stars for the following addition I made: I took part of the batter once mixed and set it in a diferent bowl, then I mashed a ripe banana very well and folded in the batter I set aside since I didn't have enough bananas for the entire batch, and oh boy they came out soooo good!! It melts in your mouth and the banana is not overpowering since it is mashed well and you don't run into pieces of bananas. TRY IT I think even if not a banana lover wich I am not you will like it. My 3 year old and 10 month old twins loved them. Next time I will make sure to have about 3 or 4 bananas to add the the batter. This recipe makes sooo much batter!

None
text:
Yum! These pankcakes are wonderful. Be sure to set out eggs, buttermilk, & milk at least 30 minutes to an hour prior to cooking... this makes them nice and fluffy. I also added a tsp of vanilla to the mix. Don't over mix when you add the dry ingredients to the wet; it's more like folding it in. The batter will be super lumpy but no worries because the flour clumps break up while cooking. You have to try this recipe, surely you'll agree that the pancakes are delicious!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely love this pancake recipe!  I make these almost every weekend.  The only thing I change is adding light buttermilk instead of regular.  I usually try to mix the egg, milk and buttermilk together early and let set, so it can start coming up to room temperature.  Also, once I learned why it is so important not to over-mix the batter, my pancakes are incredible. Just mix the batter until everything starts to come together, there will still be lumps and streaks of flour.  Then let sit for 5 minutes before adding to skillet, this will allow the baking soda to do its job and the pancakes will turn out light and fluffy.  Great recipe.

text:
The best pancakes I've ever made. My family loves them! I make them every weekend now. For a family of 4, this is the perfect amount. I halved the ingredients the first time and did not have enough. If I have extra, I also freeze them and they are great later. I don't have buttermilk, but I do as the other reviewers suggest, and add a tsp. of cider to the milk. I also make my own yogurt regularly, and adding 1/2 cup of yogurt to the milk ingredients works well to make the buttermilk and cream.

text:
This is the best pancake recipe I have ever tried! They're light, fluffy and delicious. Usually, I cut the recipe in half, because this makes a lot more than my family of 3 can finish. If you make more than you need, the batter keeps well in the fridge and the finished pancakes freeze well too. Also, these are great with blueberries, chocolate chips ands other add ins. Use about 1 cup of any add in for the full recipe.

None
text:
We made these FABULOUS pancakes this AM.  I was a little iffy at first after reading the reviews, whether to have the batter sit out, the eggs and milks at room temp., and or leaving the batter in the fridge overnight.  Well we pretty much followed the recipe as is and they turned out fantastic.  But just a note, if you have a butter spray, that may be used in sub. for actual butter.  I tried both this AM, and the butter gives it a little toasty crunch while the spray was a little on the lighter side.  Thank you for this recipe!

text:
Burygold, You nailed it!  These are outstanding pancakes; the best I've ever made, too.  I made them exactly as the recipe states.  I keep a jar of vanilla sugar on hand, and used that for the sugar called for in the recipe.   My husband just raved about them.  Can't wait to try them with some banana's or chopped apples or blueberries added.  Thanks for posting this recipe.
01/30/2011- I've been making these for a while since I first reviewed them, and what I've come to appreciate about this particular recipe is how easy it is to scale this recipe quanity, up or down, myself.  The ingredient quantites and so nicely even.   I also like that you can adjust the thickness of the cake by adding or reducing the milk in the recipe. I add fruit to it as I pour the batter on the griddle, I get better distribution and it doesn't thin or discolor the batter (blueberries!)  This is still the best recipe I've ever used and is the only one I'll ever use!  They are So good!

Display Name:

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Whoa,whoa,whoa, this recipe ALWAYS makes a large group-worth of pancakes.  I make it for a family of 5 & usually have a full meal's worth left over. I've been making this exact same recipe that I got from mrbreakfast.com & have loved it from the beginning.  Guests alway comment on how thick & fluffy my cakes are.  When we're visiting family & they make boxed pancake, it reminds me exactly why I have purchased the boxed batter i over two years. My alterations: 1) For the buttermilk, I add 3 Tbl wt. vinegar+enough milk to = 3 cup, stir & let sit while I continue prepping batter.   2) I agree with others about letting milk & eggs warm which results in fluffier cakes.  3) I add a few dashes of cinnamon into the dry mix.   This gives it that real fresh, homemade quality that's rare in the majority of pancake recipes. I've got mixed thoughts about the batter sitting prior to browning.  I've heard both conflicting recommendations from very knowledgable cooks.  Some swear, you must NOT mix dry & wet product until your griddle is completely ready, not a moment before.  Yet others, like some sugg'd here, say let batter sit anywhere from a couple minutes to let things set up to days in the fridge.  I've only let them sit prob'ly 20 mins at most, don't know if ever truely noticed a huge difference (ea of my batches tend to be different, as pancake batters usually are extremely tempermental)  Plan on trying to let sit over night as sugg'd next time I make these, usually every Sunday

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok so I had never made pancakes before from scratch figuring the boxed mixes were quite fine. But then I had some buttermilk left over from another recipe,had some time to spare on a rainy Saturday morning and I decided to try my hand at these. Well, I will never use a mix again! These were delicious. It's just me so I cut the servings down to 4 (one third of the ingredients). Other than that I followed the recipe exactly. I did let the butter cool completely before adding to the other wet ingredients and I let the wet ingredients sit for about an hour prior to mixing.(as suggested by other reviewers) I was also very careful not to over mix. The pancakes were sooo light and incredibly fluffy.Delectable even without syrup. Easily the best pancakes I have ever had! The recipe does yield a lot though because even after I thirded it, I used a 1/2 cup measuring cup and still ended up with 5 large pancakes. Watch the heat too if you are using an electric stove..medium heat was too high and scorched my first one..

I consider myself to be a pancake snob - and this recipe passed my test.  In fact, I can't remember ever making or eating a lighter, fluffier pancake - and I didn't even have buttermilk on hand. These were fabulous, and I want to thank "burygold" for the treasure!

Awesome recipe, very easy. Only change I made was to separate the eggs. The yolks got mixed with the milk mixture, and the I beat the whites to soft peaks. Once the milk mixture was mixed with the dry ingredients, I folded in the whites until they were JUST BARELY incorporated. Very very fluffy pancakes.

What is Shrove Tuesday without pancakes and this is the best recipe by far.  Made these exactly as written and the pancakes were over 1/2 inch high. I have 3 men (2 teenage football players) and for our family of 5 this was a perfect batch size.  Don't usually buy buttermilk as I never aquired the taste for it, unlike my Irish father, so to tip the hat to Grandpa, we'll add to our favorites.

text:
These are great! I actually modified a bit based on what I have and the fact that it's just me and hubby and we didn't want leftovers. I did 1/3 the recipe (4 servings), which made 4 thick 6-inch pancakes - perfect! Also, used self-rising flour and left out the baking soda, salt, etc (didn't have all-purpose). Also didn't have buttermilk, so used 1 Tbsp white vinegar and then topped it up with whole milk to reach 1 cup. Sizzled each one in butter in the pan over med-hi heat till full of bubbles and edges looked done - YUM!!

text:
Absolutely amazing pancakes, and only takes about 3 minutes longer than Bisquick.  Fluffy, beautiful texture, and amazing taste. 

I added 1 tsp vanilla, and as for the procedure, I put the butter in a 2 cup Pyrex measuring cup, melted it, let it sit for about 5 minutes, then while vigorously whisking the butter, streamed the beaten eggs into it, then stirred that mix into the milks.  Poured the whole thing into the bowl of dry items, stirred 17 times, and voila.  

YUMMY!!!!!

text:
This recipe is absolutely awesome!!  I had some leftover buttermilk to use...but realized that I didn't have any milk after everything was already mixed.  So, I used heavy cream since it was only a half cup.  I took the advice of others and added a tablespoon of lemon juice and allowed it to sit overnight!  Also please add a teaspoon (or two) of vanilla!!!  This does make a ton of batter, but I am doing quite well with using it by myself.  Also, cook on medium low heat..medium is too high and will cook too quickly!!

userID:
608121
Display Name:
W.C.E.
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

17

162

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My cousing from the U.K. was here in the U.S. so I wanted to make a breakfast treat for her.  And these pancakes were UNBELIEVABLE!!!  I had checked out some of the reviews from others before going ahead, as I'm not a big pancake fan--there is always something that I can critique about them.  However, with these...
WoW!!!
I had added some of the tips of having the buttermilk, eggs & butter at room temperature.  Separating the dry ingredients from the wet ingredients.  And added my personal touch of having the sugar mixed with 2 tspn of cinnamon and 1 tspn of nutmeg to add to the dry ingredients afterwards.  Then I incorporated the idea of beating the egg WHITES into a meringue like state with stiff peaks.  Mixed the sugar mixture, with the dry ingredients.  Mixed the dry with the wet ingredients.  Then added the "meringue-like" whites into the fold.  Added a cup of blueberries, some extract (vanilla/pineapple).  Though tempted, I made sure not to OVER STIR the mix and began making the first batch of pancakes...

And I was in HEAVEN!!!  

MMMMMMMMMMMMM!

They were thick, HUGE pancakes that had a beautiful golden brown appearance; yet, but inside were light and moist when eating them.  The cup of blueberries added were just PERFECT!  I seldomly write reviews, but I had too!  As these were DEFINITELY the BEST pancakes I've had!  Will be making plenty more for sure!  Again, thanks for sharing this recipe!

Made these last night for a quick dinner. Heat the griddle over high heat till it was hot, then turned the heat to medium high.
