We change the portion to 4 people and that is perfect for me and my husband. We continue to have a problem with the thickness and cook time. I think it is my stove top...in order to get it to cook all the way through, it nearly blackens on the outside...I have added a little more milk at times to thin it and that helped but then they weren't as fluffy. The flavor is great though and we plan to keep trying until we find the right temperature for cooking!

Finally a from scratch pancake recipe that worth the trouble.  I followed the recipe to the letter, except I didn't have fresh buttermilk (used a powdered version), but they still turned out terrific! Absolute keeper, and probably even better when I get my hands on fresh buttermilk!

FABULOUS!  These are the best buttermilk pancakes ever.  Sometimes, when "in season" I'll use eggnog for the milk.  I also have to add more milk to make them thinner... I'm not crazy about cakey pancakes.  I had my hubby mix them up for me yesterday and he even made a little ooops with tsp and tbs measuring (tried to fix it and apparently did), but it still turned out terrific.  I like to make up a big batch, so I can keep them in the freezer and pop them in the microwave for breakfast on school days.  SSSOOOO GOOOD!!!  I feel like a pro when I make these up!  Thanks for such a simple, delicious recipe.  Ever since this pancake recipe, I will ONLY make the box-mixed kind when I have no buttermilk or less time.  There is no comparison.

text:
Honestly - I'm not sure what everyone is raving about.  I made these pancakes for breakfast and I wasn't overly impressed.  My tastebuds, and those of my husband, weren't shouting "WOW"  *lol*

I did add vanilla - and would definitely make that recommendation for everyone.

If you're looking to scale the recipe down - your best bet is to scale it to a proper measurement - such as 8 or 4.  Otherwise you are left with a recipe which calls for 1 1/2 eggs... not exactly something most people will be able to figure out how to do.  If you scale the recipe to 8 or 4 - you will get easier measurements.

text:
I am definitely a big pancake fan and I usually don't have a problem with pancakes but for some reason these just don't sit well with me.  I've made them twice to give it a fair shot but maybe it's too much baking powder?  They were kinda bland the first time so I added some sugar and vanilla which did improve the flavor, but other than being a bit too spongy for me, they just didn't do it.  So far I like the truck stop buttermilk pancakes and I still have more to try!  My boys really enjoyed them, but these just weren't the pancake for me.

Best pancakes I have ever had and I don't really care for pancakes, just a tip not that this is a must for extra fluffy pancakes I use 3 oz milk 1 oz ginger ale or seltzer, to the liquid mixture.  Also I seperate the eggs and beat the whites until they are nice and stiff and add them after I have combied the other ingredients mix in and let everything sit for 5 minutes so that eveything can meld together.

I'm a pancake-aholic and these were truly delicious!  I scaled the recipe to 4 servings and it still made 6, 5 inch pancakes (perfect for hubby and I!).  I added (to my scaled down recipe, so times 3 for the full recipe) 1/2 tsp. pumpkin pie spice, 1/4 tsp. cinnamon, and instead of 1 tbsp. sugar I used 3 tbsp of sugar.  I also added 1 tsp. vanilla.  I served them with the Cinnamon Apple Syrup recipe on this site (highly recommend it, it was awesome!).  Enjoy!

I highly doubt that one half egg extra dispersed throughout 20 medium sized pancakse makes a world of difference, making me believe that if I had followed this recipe exactly without halfing it it would still taste WAY too eggy. It's getting 2 stars since I halved the recipe and maybe that's what messed it up, but I doubt it.  I make pancakes all the time with no problem and should have stuck to my traditional recipe.

text:
This is a great recipe, but I scaled it down to 4 servings for my 2 toddlers and altered it a little. For the small recipe I added 1 extra TBSP sugar, 3/4 tsp vanilla, and about 1/4-1/2 tsp orange peel. Besides having all ingredients at room temperature (which makes it fluffier!), I didn't use fresh buttermilk. I just added 1 TBSP of lemon juice to a measuring cup then filled it up to the 1 cup mark with regular milk and let it set for about 5 minutes. 1 Cup of instant buttermilk and it worked just fine in the recipe.

I substituted heavy whipping cream for milk, but kept everything else the same. Don't overmix the batter, leave it a little bit Lumpy. Add a bunch of butter to the skillet and let it melt then pour the pancake batter right in the middle. The pancakes turned out fluffy, crispy from the butter on the edges and absolutely fabulous! I totally recommend making them.

I love this recipe. I used to make buttermilk pancakes years ago, but have not done it for ages. I looked up this recipe and it looked similar. text:
My husband and I were never pancake fans but in the last couple of years that has changed. These came out amazingly fluffy and delicious. I was reading how some other reviews said they were watery - I’d make sure that you measured correctly and used the exact ingredients. The biggest tip - DO NOT STIR the dry and wet ingredients together; fold them in just enough to get everything wet and then let sit while griddle heats. Amazing!  I made a blueberry sauce from Allrecipes to top them and oh my gosh!!  Thank you for sharing.

I was looking for a recipe that mimicked this pancake house I once went to and THIS IS IT.  After seeing the 2k plus reviews and that over 5k have made this I knew it had to be good.  I reduced the recipe to a third and used all the correct ingredients except I exchanged sugar for brown sugar (it's all I had)...came out amazing.  This is a keeper. text:
Best. Pancakes. Ever.  I have tried any and all pancake recipes I could find; until I came across this one.  It looked a little overwhelming with a large quantity of ingredients but I decided to give it a go due to it using buttermilk.  A last ditch effort to see if buttermilk was the secret ingredient.  I LOVE these pancakes, and here’s why:  They taste amazing, the recipe yields twelve large pancakes,  they freeze well and only take a minute to heat from frozen in the microwave.  When I make a batch at the weekend, we have leftovers for the week.  Unless, of course we have company (it’s usually just the two of us); then I look like an amazing cook :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this pancake recipe , as written, several times.  Now I just make 2/3 of a recipe which yields about 12-13 pancakes (1/3 c batter per cake).  Also, I found that I can substitute oil for the butter to simplify prep.  These pancakes are better than any other recipe I have tried and better than those I have had eating out.   For 2/3's recipe use 1 pint (2c) buttermilk,  6 Tbsp milk, 3 1/2 Tbsp oil,   2 eggs, dash vanilla and mix together.  Dry ingredients: 2 c flour, 2 Tbsp Sugar, 2 tsp baking powder, 1 tsp b. soda, 1/2 tsp salt.  Mix the dry ingredients ahead so you can whip these up in no time at all.

region:

country:
None
text:
These are my new favorite. These pancakes turn out fluffy and the flavor is mildly sweet and oh so buttery. I absolutely love these pancakes and now I even crave them at a treat. 

Do not worry about the lumpy bumpy texture of the batter. Waiting until the last minute to mix is important... so if you have extra batter use it up. Better to save and reheat the tasty pancakes. They just don't cook well the next day. You will end up with super thin odd shaped cakes if you try to save it overnight. (but they'll still taste good...)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an amazing recipe!  I used vegetable oil instead of butter, and they still turned out buttery and delicious.  

One tip regarding the buttermilk:  buy a quart of it, use 3 cups of it for this recipe, then refill the quart container with more milk and shake well.  Allow to sit out for 8-12 hours, shaking occasionally, then refrigerate.  This gives you another whole quart of buttermilk!  Use within about 2 weeks, and, when you do use it, repeat the process!  You'll have infinite buttermilk!
Review:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband is a pancake aficionado and I have been on a quest to find a pancake that he raves over. I've tried many wonderful pancake recipes on this site including some that he has complimented, but this is the recipe that beat out all the others with his rave reviews. The pancake is soft, tender, and fluffy. The flavor of the buttermilk is subtle and doesn't overpower the butter and syrup. I'm way too lazy to mix two different bowls with wet and dry ingredients. Instead, I mixed the wet ingredients, then added in all the dry ingredients except the baking powder and baking soda, mixing well. When my grill was hot and I was ready to start cooking, I added the baking powder and baking soda and blended it in well. They came out absolutely perfect. Thank you for a great recipe!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6880590.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love breakfast and especially pancakes.  A while after my mom died when I was a kid, my dad began dating a woman who lived about a mile away.  When she found out I loved pancakes, she offered to make me some if I made my way to her house.  I walked the mile one Saturday morning and was rewarded with delicious homemade pancakes!  They later married! :-) 

These pancakes were everything BuryGold said they'd be. They were fluffy and golden brown.  I didn't think pancakes with such simple ingredients could be so much better than those from a mix!  I think what helped greatly was not over-mixing and, of course, the rich buttermilk!  Thank you BuryGold for giving me the chance to make a wonderful breakfast for my family and to recollect a happy childhood memory!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5483461.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my go-to pancake recipe.   If I make 1/3 the recipe it yields two very large 8" pancakes.  I often make 2/3 the recipe and freeze the extra pancakes for another day.  That's enough for several breakfasts in my house.   Light and fluffy.   Your griddle needs to be hot enough that water splashed on rolls around and disappears in a second.  And don't overmix the batter.   I throw the wet ingredients into the dry and stir lightly with a fork just until you can't see any loose dry ingredients.  It  will look thick and lumpy.

userID:
1414774
Display Name:
AUSSIEMUM1
isPro:
False
followersCount:
45

madeRecipesCount:
223
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/23546.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is phenomenal!

Okay, I have a LOT of homemade kefir to use up, which is basically cultured sour milk. Kind of like buttermilk. It's thickish and slightly tart/sour so I used my homemade kefir for this recipe instead of bought buttermilk. 

I also used self raising flour and omitted the baking powder. I live in Australia so using self raising flour is fine. 

I will say that there is a top review that says to leave little lumps of flour in the mix and they'll break open on the pan. Well, they do and they don't. I didn't overmix, so some lumps remained in the actual pancake and when it was cut in half, a small lump of flour was still there. So you want to mix it to make sure most obvious lumps are gone but leave some. 

The finished product looks like an awesome fluffy version of McDonald's hotcakes. A real keeper to use with kefir. 

I made two batches and froze them in lots of three, so my kids could heat them in the microwave for breakfast on days when I go to work early.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
My family loves these!! I added 1.5 TB of vanilla and it added a really nice flavor. To add chocolate chips or blueberries or whatever extra you want, coat in flour then add to batter; it keeps them from falling all the way to the bottom of the batter. Very delicious, and very easy!! Make your own buttermilk if you don’t have any on hand: 1 TB of lemon juice or white vinegar to 1 cup of milk and let stand 5 minutes. Perfection!

text:
When I was in High School I worked for IHOP. I know how to cook from a mix. I used to use off the counter pancake mix and substitute buttermilk plus a lil extra for whole milk, 
I decided to try this recipe.I cut the recipe in half, used 2 jumbo eggs and 1 1/2 + 3/4 cups buttermilk no whole milk, turned out great made 12 ±5" light fluffy pancakes. I think next time I will add a little vanilla extract. For the idiots that cannot cook, when  something is burnt on the outside & undercooked inside you are cooking with your pan  too hot, try this old fashioned remedy, turn the heat down a little, it will take a lil longer to cook, but it will cook through.

text:
My husband loved it and gave it 5 stars. He didn't even put syrup on it, that's how good it is. I used coconut sugar. Also, for the 6 servings I was going to cook, instead of 1.5 eggs, I used 1 egg and 1/2 a flax egg. I also used the vinegar/milk method to make buttermilk (1 Tb of vinegar in each 1 cup of milk and let sit for 5 minutes) It's been comical around here how I've managed to mess up pancakes since I always try to make healthy ones with pumpkin or zucchini. Finally I just said "I promise I'll make you regular pancakes today."

userID:
14066509
Display Name:
Karen E. Duffy
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
17
favoritesCount:
110
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4586339.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Finally, a pancake recipe that makes perfect (in our opinion) pancakes worthy of any pancake house, but easily made at home.  I made 6 servings and since I didn't want to use part of an egg, I used 2 lg. eggs.  I substituted 1/2 cup whole wheat flour for 1/2 cup of the all-purpose, and used 6 tbl. powdered buttermilk to 1 1/2 cup of water, whisked and added to the liquid ingredients.   Also added some cinnamon and a couple squeezes of agave nectar and maple syrup to the liquid ingredients.  They came out wonderful! I thought the batter might be too thin, but my hubby and I like our pancakes on the thin side, and these were just right.  Made a ton of batter, enough for two, plus several that I cooked up and stored in the fridge.  I like mine with syrup and  completely covered with cinnamon (YUM).  My husband has in the past rated my homemade pancakes as "okay" or "so-so."  These he really liked, ("really good!") served with breakfast link sausages.  This will be my go-to pancake recipe from now on.  Thank you for posting this!

text:
I love pancakes and make mostly the "normal" (big and not fluffy) variety because I'm German and live in Spain, we eat different ones :-). .

But this pancakes have change my mind: they are the BEST!

Savory (due to the buttermilk), fluffy (baking powder and bicarb) and very quick to make.


Normally I let them stand for 30 minutes but for this ones the dry and wet  ingredients are  mixed at the last moment just before frying. 

And even so they are thicker they back very quickly.

I think we will have pancakes this week again lol.
Maybe this time with some herbs thrown in and a savory topping.... hmmmmm, can't wait :-)))).

Thank you  Burygold for sharing your recipe :-).

Display Name:
Becky S.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
You cannot go wrong with this recipe.  I have made it twice and scaled down the recipe to half and it still made 9 pancakes about 4-5 inches in diameter.   I used the EXACT recipe but added 1 teaspoon of Lemon juice to the well mixed wet batter.  I read a review where the acid in the Lemon juice only makes them lighter in combination with the other ingredients. and you cannot taste the lemon juice.  Don't over-mix the batter when you add the wet to the dry.  Let it sit 15-20 minutes before  frying the pancakes.  The prepared mix will be full of bubbles prior to cooking.  I used the back of my ladle to smooth the pancakes out to make them thinner on my griddle.

I've made this several times and it beats the pants off pancake mix. Light & fluffy, these pancakes don't sit heavy in the belly after the meal. I use milk & vinegar to create buttermilk every time and it works great. The recipe does make a heaping pile of flapjacks. I love this recipe and won't ever make another.

text:
I did only make half a batch and glad I did as it would have made way to much for 2 people. I did add 1 t. vanilla, 1/4 cup cooking oil instead of melted butter. They came out perfect and I didn't even have ingredients room temperature. I made sure not to over mix so used a spatula and folded the wet ingred. into the dry. Don't overheat grill. I let them cook slowly. Turning them to soon can make a mess. Easier to make small ones than large. Beautiful finish. We used homemade apple butter topped with whipped cream instead of syrup. Can't wait to try this when I have company. A keeper for sure.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just so all of you know, DO NOT START WITH A LOT OF OIL, because it will make your pancakes very oily. Also, DO NOT TURN YOUR OVEN ON MEDIUM-HIGH, because it will turn out to burn, while still raw inside. If you just start on a medium-low heat, then your pancakes will actually cook on the inside. Otherwise, this isn't all that bad of a recipe, but it's not like especially good and unresistable.

text:
I don't think the recipe says that it makes 12 pancakes but that it serves 12. However, although it makes a lot o pancakes, I also don't think it feeds 12 people. I've made these twice. The first time, I made 2/3 of the recipe and fed 3 adults. I didn't had maple syrup so I thought the pancakes need a bit of sugar ( I added 25-30g). Tonight, I had a sweet craving and made 1/3 of the recipe just for me :D but it would be more than enough for 2 people. Because in the first atempt I thought it needed extra sugar, I added a bit of sugar too in this batch, but with maple syrup the extra sugar was too much. They should be awesome as they are. Thank you guys

These are the melt-in-your-mouth fluffy pancakes I remember!  Cook on almost low, it's worth the wait for the griddle to heat up - oh and wait for the bubbles to form on top and break without filling in the bubble - this ensures you only flip once and the middle will be done.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were a hit with my family.  However, I made a couple of changes.  I soaked half a cup of oatmeal in the milk overnight and added it to the batter the next day.  I reduced the sugar by half and sprinkled in some cinnamon.  I also added two teaspoons of vanilla.  I did not have any buttermilk, so I squeezed some lemon juice in milk to sour overnight.

I followed the recipe exactly and these came out wonderfully. text:
I usually cut everything in half because there is just the two of us and that is plenty. Comes out really well. We also add mini chocolate chips and double the butter. 

TIPS:
If you feel that the mix is running too thin. Add spoon full of flower and mix in. Keep doing this until you have reached your desired thickness. 

Extray chrispy edges! I cook bacon first on a electric skillet and capture all the runoff. Then I clarify the grease and use that instead of butter to cook the pancake on.

text:
Represents a bit of a holy grail for me... wanted to replicate my favourite Hot Cake House in Portland OR,  and this is the closest I have come and I'm so happy!! So key to not mix too much to ensure fluffiness, I also use Eastern European fermented milk (like Bulgarian yoghurt) as it works good every time and easy to get in London, sugar is also optional IMO and I find the eggy flavour comes out nicer without it. these are perfect for loading blueberries, banana, choc chip into to make some pretty darn awesome breakfasts. I've shown these off countless times and can now bust them out super quick. Much love to you for posting these!

None
country:
None
text:
If you are looking for the perfect buttermilk pancake, then this recipe is it.  My (almost) 2-year-old son requested pancakes for breakfast so I thought I would try this recipe.  Everything mixed up so fast and I know he loved them - he ate 3 of them!  I didn't have buttermilk on hand, so I just put 1 Tablespoon of lemon juice in a 1-cup measuring cup and filled it to the 1-cup line with whole milk (I only made 1/3 of the recipe)... these were so good, I don't foresee ever going out of my way to have buttermilk on hand for this recipe.  I also added a little bit of vanilla and a little bit of cinnamon, because I add them to almost anything sweet that I make.  Wonderful recipe!

Very good pancakes. My only tip is to make sure the milk and eggs are room temp before adding the melted butter. If not, the butter will re-harden in the milk leaving gross chunks of butter.

text:
Delicious, but this makes a lot!  The second time I made them, I cut the recipe into thirds since it calls for 3 eggs.  I also added some flaxseed meal to add a healthy component, since my son is a picky eater and he doesn't mind that.  It doesn't change the flavor, just makes the color slightly darker.  Happy to finally have a real homemade pancake recipe, instead of using Bisquick.  My plan is to make Irish Soda Bread when I make these, since that bread recipe I use calls for buttermilk also.  Or I may make the full batch & try freezing some pancakes in a ziploc bag next time. Thanks again for another wonderful recipe!

text:
I made it just as written, and with cold buttermilk right out of the fridge. Turned out perfectly. My five little ones asked for seconds and even thirds. There was a crispy 'crust' on them that was awesome. I think the key is NOT OVERSTIRRING.  The batter  looked a bit lumpy, but I only stirred until the wet ingredients were no longer wet, then quit stirring. The recipe made A TON of pancakes, but that's a good thing in my book :) Will definitely make again! Delicious!

country:
None
text:
Cut the recipe by 1/3 which made three 6"- 8" pancakes for me and my wife. I've been making homemade kefir and used that instead of the buttermilk. Also substituted the sugar with avocado honey and agave. I added just enough sweetener until the liquid part was no longer bitter. The really cool part was when I added the dry mixture into the wet mixture it started rising. That's because the kefir contains live natural probiotics including yeast. So immediately the yeast produced CO2 and made the most incredible pancakes.

text:
So right off the bat, buttermilk tends to come in 4-cup containers. Adjust the recipe to 16 servings instead of 12. Nobody likes waste. ;) 

Second, I HIGHLY recommend adding blueberries to these because they make THE best blueberry pancakes on the face of the earth. 

Make the recipe as is, add berries, be very careful to not overmix, and being your self control so you don't inhale too many. You really don't need syrup, but my kids still love them with it. 

Now, if you excuse me, I'm off to go pick raspberries to try with the next batch of these flapjacks of heaven.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I like a thicker/fluffy pancake. This batter was, like many others stated, too runny. I used big spoon to stir, not over-stir, and it flattened out in pan, crepe-like. bummer. (I did buttermilk substitute of milk/vinegar and added 1/4c plain greek yogurt for the smooth texture it helps to give instead of too airy cake, as well as had eggs/milk room temp first).  

 I added 2 MORE cups of AP flour, sifted (i added 1/4c at time until i got a pancake I liked) and 1 Tbsp more baking powder. BOOM! My pancakes were about 3/4" thick. More dense, but I like it that way.  I believe there's 1 too many eggs and not enough flour for the original recipe.

This made about 24 pancakes. Mine are 4-5" diameter, smaller for my lil ones.

text:
I followed the recipe exactly. The directions said not to over stir. I was hesitant about that because the mixture was so lumpy, but sure enough the lumps disappeared once the cakes were on the griddle.  These were by far the BEST pancakes I have ever tasted! I will definitely make them again! Our family of three had lots leftover from this batch, so we individually wrapped the leftover pancakes in plastic wrap (once they were cooled) and put them in a large ziplock freezer bag, and put them in the freezer.  On busy mornings, we pull the frozen pancakes out and let them thaw a bit, then pop them in the toaster or the microwave for a delicious breakfast.

text:
These pancakes were so delicious and a cinche to make! I did want to note, like many of the previous reviews...it would have been helpful to leave the buttermilk and eggs out to get to room temperature... I did not and once I added the melted butter it immediately hardened. So before adding the wet ingredients to the dry ingredients I put the milk mixture in the microwave long enough to re-melt some of the butter. Once everything was combined everything turned out great!!!

The batter was a bit thick for our taste  so I thinned it with about a 1/4 c more milk.  However, these pancakes were light, fluffy and had great flavor!  I disregard the critique that this recipe doesn't make a fluffy pancake.  We found them to be quite light and tender.  Use fresh baking powder and don't over mix the batter.  It's a good recipe and I'll use it again.   It does make a lot of batter!

text:
I have made this recipe 3 times in the last couple of weeks.  It is an excellent recipe.  However, after the first time, I have been doubling the amount of salt called for.  The recipe calls for 1/4 tsp. salt per cup of flour, I use 1/2 tsp. per cup.  I also use honey rather than sugar and combine that with the other liquid ingredients, and I prefer unbleached white flour.  In any case, the pancakes turn out consistently delicious, and this is not much more difficult than using a boxed mix.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
made according to instructions. Best pancakes I've ever had, let alone made. The only 'special' thing i did was my technique. I used a 1/4cp size instead of 1/2cp b/c these were mostly for my young kids (3/4/6yrs old), I used a nonstick griddle, no butter or spray. I cooked on a low temp as opposed to med b/c they were cooking too fast for me and browning too much for our liking. We don't like our pancakes rising too much (1/2in thick+) so I was using my 1/4cp to spread the batter out thinner after pouring onto the griddle and when I flipped them and they started to rise 'too' much I gently pushed some of the air out. The result was soft  and weighty pancake(no more than 1/4in thick), (i'd liken it to an ihop pancake, my previous favorite).

text:
My kids think these are way better than IHOP pancakes! They can be picky when it comes to pancakes, but these I couldn't cook fast enough haha! I followed the recipe exactly, only I didn't oil/butter my nonstick electric griddle. I also followed the most helpful reviewers advice and let my combined eggs, milk, and buttermilk sit out for an hour (longer for me) to reach room temp. This helps them become more fluffy, or so I read...and wow mine were! I didn't need my oven to keep the extra warm because  my husband and 3 daughters ate them so fast! If you are able to set the temp on your griddle, 375 F is the perfect temperature, and for me 1:10-1:20 on each side was perfect. So thank you again allrecipes, I am yet again the best cook in the world haha! This recipe will be replacing my old one, and used again and again!

text:
Just as easy as bisquick pancakes (ultimate melt in your mouth version) but even better.  This will be my go to going forward.  Helpful (but not necessary): 
-Cut the recipe in half for 2 large pancakes each for 3 people. (Still had about a cup left over)
Add 1 tsp lemon juice to the halved recipe (so 2 tsp if using the full)
Milk, butter milk, eggs and melted butter to room temp before mixing
DON'T mix out the lumps (never do!)
The longer the batter sits the fluffier your pancakes will be

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe. Buttermilk is expensive in Australia, so I just mixed 3 cups of milk with a 1/4 cup white vinegar and let it sit for 20 mins - does the same thing. 

I also, barely mixed the batter, using a fork. I was sweating bullets as it was a very thin batter with lumps of flour, so i let it sit for 10 mins - and the bicarb and baking powder did it magic then and it started bubbling up, but they turned out high, incredibly fluffy and soft. A massive hit with my family.  

The quantities mentioned makes enough for a big breakfast for 4 adults, I found.  And I used a 1/2 cup measuring cup of batter for each pancake.

All said, an absolutely amazing recipe, just make sure you don't overmix. Don't be scared by flour Lumps - whatever you do, don't mix this into a smooth batter. This recipe has become my go to pancake recipe for now on.

text:
3-20-2016  ~I swear Hubs forgot his manners this morning.  He had his breakfast half eaten before I even sat down to eat mine!  (Taking pictures of your food can do that)  And while he was eating he kept repeating, “Ohhh, these are good.  I can’t remember the last time I had pancakes.”  Mm-hm, they were good.  And I was a little unsure they would be, since I found I only had 1/4 cup of buttermilk (for recipe scaled to 4 servings, which required 1 cup of buttermilk).  I thought the scientific ratio of leaveners to milk vs. buttermilk (acid) might be disturbed since I had to fill in the rest with milk but it worked out fine. (In other words, theoretically this could have been too much baking soda since the amount of buttermilk had been significantly reduced.)  It’s been said over and over again from a gagillion sources that when making pancakes, one of the most critically important things is that you resist the temptation to stir the lumps out.  Leave some lumps and making great pancakes is a piece of CAKE.  (Couldn’t resist that one) And let the batter set a few minutes before you start.  As for this recipe, this has just the right amount of sugar, which I sometimes think is there just to mask ANY taste of baking powder, which is unpleasant. Just the right amount of salt too.   All the way around, a good, reliable and obviously quite forgiving recipe.

Display Name:
Jodyisadiva

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My pancakes came out Terrific! I made buttermilk banana pancakes with the recipe. I followed the recipe as shown except I didn't have any buttermilk. 

So, I made "buttermilk" from scratch which is 1 cup of milk to 1Tbsp of Vinagar or you can use 1Tbsp of lemon juice. I used both since I made 8 servings. 

You have to let the buttermilk mixture sit for 8-10 mins before you add it to the dry ingredients.  

For the bananas I added 1 1/2  of over riped bananas in a separate bowl. 1Tbsp sugar 2 Tspn of vanilla extract. A dash of nutmeg & cinnamon.  Crush the bananas with a fork until it gets creamy looking. 

Then, I combine all the ingredients just as followed and the bananas. just mix it good with a fork or you can use your wisk. 

Add a little bit of unsalted butter to your frying pan or skillet and voila!! 

TIP: you would know when the pancakes are ready to flip when you start to notice little tiny air bubbles on top of the pancakes. ;)

text:
We finally found a pancake recipe we all love! I keep buttermilk on hand just for this recipe. We like these pancakes because they are not thick and fluffy, but thinner and less doughy. If you are looking for a thick pancake, these are not for you. But we love them just the way the recipe was written. This recipe makes quite a few - more than enough for my husband, 3 kids, and myself.

Display Name:
amysmhuang

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It turned out very fluffy! You definitely have to use good fresh buttermilk. If you don't have that try "Fluffy Pancakes Recipe" on Allrecipes which calls for souring milk with vinegar (it really works). A few small adjustments. Added 1 tsp vanilla extract, and since I only have sea salt, I used a little bit less than the recipe called for otherwise it would have been too salty. Also since they are fluffy and thick, it needs more cooking time than normal pancakes. Use lower heat, flip when bubbling and then give it a little more time. Poke in the middle to make sure it's cooked through. Also, 1/3 of the recipe is perfect for 2 hungry eaters.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
This has become my go to recipie for pancakes since I hate pancakes from a mix. I've added all kinds of extras (bananas, blueberries, mini chocolate chips, brown sugar and cinnamon) and they come out great every time. It took me finding the right heat level so they don't cook too fast or slow and rise just right. I find a medium-low heat works best for me, and butter for the pan of course!

text:
I was looking for a buttermilk pancake recipe that did not taste too much like the baking powder/soda, where it doesn't give off a bit of an almost sour taste. 

This recipe did the trick. I had some mushy blueberries which I wanted to use, and not waste. I ended up adding some frozen ones as well because this recipe makes a lot of pancakes. 

The pancakes came out airy and without the "soda" taste. I did however adjust the baking powder to 2 teaspoons, and baking soda to 1 teaspoon. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Would definitely make these again! However, I did make a few adjustments. I used 1 1/2 c all purpose flour and 1 1/2 c whole wheat flour and a 1/4c wheat bran. I omitted sugar (syrup and fresh fruit seem to add enough sweetness). I used 1 1/2 c buttermilk and 1 1/2 c almond milk. Added cinnamon and freshly grated nutmeg. These pancakes cooked up very fluffy and evenly done.  Thanks for a wonderful recipe!

text:
This recipe is AMAZING. Everyone, including myself, loved them. Warning: the original recipe proportions are outrageous. I halved the recipe, and ended up with 15 pancakes, just enough for me and my family to have three each. Also, I recommend beating the eggs in a separate bowl, and then add them to the milk. Cracking them directly into the liquid makes it very difficult to mix them.

text:
My uncle had a similar recipe and I lost it over the years.  I was so bummed because I recall these being the lightest, fluffiest, yet most flavorful pancake in the world.  I must say, these were as good if not even a little better!  If you get something other than a light and fluffy pancake, you are doing something wrong.  You MUST be precise in your baking soda, baking powder and salt measurements.  THESE are the ingredients that give it the light and fluffy texture.  This is now my GO TO recipe. Seriously, if you want to impress someone with your pancake skills, make these! Thank you for sharing!!

text:
These were delicious and I don't even like pancakes, was just making them for my family! The only issues I had were my own fault. I added the melted butter before it cooled down and it made big lumps in the batter, but did not affect cooking or taste whatsoever. I also didn't have as much buttermilk as I thought, so I just made a substitute with vinegar and milk. Voila! Super tasty pancakes! The batter was not runny at all, the pancakes weren't too thick, and they were definitely not flat like some have stated. Oh, do add a bit of vanilla extract to add extra flavor!

Display Name:
Maria

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/914561.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
One trick guaranteed to work that achieves the fluffiest, most tender pancakes possible is to mix the batter as gently as you can and for the least amount of time as is possible.  You want a very lumpy batter with streaks of flour throughout.  Try preparing it this way once and see if it doesn't greatly improve your results.  As for the actual recipe, I follow it to a T with no changes and they are PERFECT.  The only real change I employ is to drop 6 - 8 blueberries on top of each pancake after pouring the batter onto to griddle.   I don't fold the blueberries into the batter, and this prevents them from breaking or discoloring the batter.
Review:
Rating:
5

None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe! To save time, I mixed up a batch of dry ingredients and stored them in a labeled jar; so every time we want a few pancakes it's just a matter of adding the wet ingredients and fry. 

For every cup of dry mix: add 1 cup milk/buttermilk, 1 egg, and 2 tbsp. oil (instead of butter), which makes about 12 small pancakes. Just like ready-to-go mix!

Omg.. these  were sooo good.  Best recipe! I didn't  want to make  a huge batch so I only  used 2 cups of flour instead  of 3 and 2 cups of buttermilk instead of 3. But followed  everything  else  to a tee. I use coconut  oil to lightly  grease  the griddle.   They were fluffy and great  flavor! Add a dash of milk if batter is a bit thick. I did because  the butter milk  was thick. Made about 15 pancakes with a 1/4 cup measuring cup for portions. Next time  I'll  do full recipe  and freeze  them :-)

Delicious, quick, and easy! 
For fluffier pancakes add 1 tablespoon of vinegar, be careful not to over-mix, and let batter rest for 5 minutes before cooking!
If you do not have buttermilk use allrecipes.com "Fluffy Pancake" (5 stars with over 7000 reviews). It is excellent too! I let this batter rest for 5 minutes too.

This recipe is superior.  Not to improve upon it, I did add 3 tbs. of orange zest, 1 tsp. vanilla, 1/2 tsp. Cardamom and 1 tbsp. pumpkin spice.  I add this to most of my pancake recipes.  Oh, and I did eliminate the 3/4 tsp. salt because of high salt intake. They were absolutely delicious. The only problem is, we (our family) couldn't quit eating them without control.  Thanks for sharing this!!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe as written(well, I did half a batch and instead of the 1 1/2 large eggs it was calling for I used 2 medium, which is a fine conversion). It was indeed fluffy, not too overpowering of a taste of buttermilk(but it definitely was there), but they seemed to lack something, which I can only assume is due to the sugar amount. I use syrup like most people, but I still feel like a pancake should have it's own level of sweetness too. You'd definitely need to up the sugar level to get it to get a pancake that tastes like most people would be familiar with. I have a recipe I really adore that has a ratio of 2 cups of All-Purpose flour to 1/4 cup + 1 Tbs sugar and that's a perfect sugar taste to me. So there's maybe a benchmark of sugar amount should you want to tinker with this recipe a little. :)

Using the fresh ground flour added a nice nuttiness to the pancakes.  I have a high-end blender that is able to perform that task in about one minute.  I dump it into a flour sifter to remove any particles.  Will make again and add blueberries. Yum.

Note, it does make a bit more than the stated amount which is fine.

text:
Great recipe! Huge hit in my house. My change was to separate out the egg whites from the yolks, mixing the yolks with the wet ingredients as instructed. Then I whipped the whites and the sugar together and incorporated it into the batter after it was all mixed together. Makes the end result even lighter and fluffier.

text:
the best thing about this recipe is that it uses 3 cups of buttermilk! so if you buy buttermilk for something (as i did) it uses it all up haha. that being said, these pancakes are good but not great. i didn't find them to be super fluffy. they were a bit lumpy when cooked (haven't had this problem with other pancakes). they were a bit too egg-y for me. and i wish they were crisp on the outside but that's just a personal preference. so overall these are good but i will try out another buttermilk pancake recipe next time. oh and they do not make too many, unless you don't like pancakes!  then why are you making this recipe anyway. i love pancake leftovers.

text:
This is a great recipe. I used all buttermilk instead of the 1/2 cup of milk and added 3 teaspoons of cinnamon. Instead of making pancakes I used a brownie/mini loaf mold to make pancake bites for my kids. I also made breakfast turkey sausage to sprinkle in between the batter as I put it in the mold. I baked @ 425*F for 10-12 mins. Came out great. Turkey sausage recipe:

1 pound ground turkey;
3 teaspoons brown sugar;
1 1/2 teaspoon salt;
1 teaspoon ground black pepper;
1 teaspoon ground sage;
1/4 teaspoon ground coriander seeds;
1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper;

This is the best pancake recipe I've ever made! I previously used store bought pancake mix, but have started trying to cook more things from scratch. I added about 1/4 Cup of sweet potato puree that I had on hand, simply because we're about to move and I needed to finish it off! I used a cast iron skillet to cook the pancakes, which gave it a more rustic, yummy-ness that I don't normally get from my electric griddle. Very easy recipe to follow, and seems like you could easily add some blueberries or chocolate chips for funnies!

text:
These were big, fluffy and delicious with maple syrup. I read a few reviews that said the batter was thin which was not the case for me.  When mixing the wet ingredients I first mixed the buttermilk and soy milk(didn't have regular milk) then I added the melted butter, a little butter started to solidify since I am not patient enough to wait for all my ingredients to come to room temp but it didn't cause any problems.  I was careful not to over mix and my batter was thick and chunky.  If you like more flavor feel free to add whatever you want, this is a great base recipe.  I'm not sure how other reviewers messed this up?  Maybe not using buttermilk or over mixing?

text:
This is a very good basic pancake recipe.  Like another reviewer, I didn't have buttermilk so used the vinegar in the milk trick. I also got a lot more pancakes out of it than the recipe states, I made it for 4 and got 7, but I made medium-sized pancakes.  I think if you made the small size you could get 12.  The recipe is simple, easy to remember and will be my regular recipe from now on.

userID:

Display Name:
bitterquill

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe almost exactly (used Country Crock, which is made with dairy, in place of plain butter, and accordingly cut the salt by 1/3). I didn't even bother to let the buttermilk mixture rest, and they turned out thick, fluffy and plenty sweet, not overly eggy or dense but surprisingly filling. The only discrepancy between the recipe and my own experience is that I only needed a 1/4-cup scoop of batter for a 5" pancake, so I ended up with a whopping 26 5" pancakes, overall, enough for four family breakfasts at our house. At that size, each contains almost exactly 100 calories and 15g carbs, according to the weight of the ingredients, and two is a perfect serving size and still acceptable for the diabetic in the household. I froze most of the batch, wrapped in wax paper (after cooling) and tucked in a large freezer bag; they reheated easily in the microwave with no nasty texture changes.

text:
I love this recipe!  The pancakes are so light, fluffy and delicious. And the great thing is that it is so easy to make a smaller portion for two. I divide it by 3...1 cup flour, 1 Tbsp sugar, 1 tsp baking powder, 1/2 baking soda,  1/4 tsp salt.   And the same with the wet ingredients.  One third of the recipe makes just enough for my husband and me. Tonight I added fresh blueberries.  So good!!!  We had them for dinner instead of breakfast.

WOW! My two-year old, who normally doesn't eat, just had five of these (silver dollar size)! Impressive. I'll make them again whenever I have freshly made butttermilk.

text:
These are simply fabulous pancakes. I didn't have 3 cups of buttermilk, so I replaced one cup with milk and lemon juice, and it's just wonderful. These are dense but fluffy and the 3 cups goes VERY far, much further than the boxed pancake mix. I also want to add that the butter congealed a bit, so I used my blender to mix up all the wet ingredients.  And now that it's been a few days and I finally used the rest of it, it's not quite as good as it was fresh. For some reason, the pancakes didn't get fluffy...they stayed pretty thin. They tasted just as good, they just weren't quite the right texture.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
allrecipes.com recipe contributors provide another great recipe with this buttermilk pancake recipe.  Because I have a food allergy in our household, I use a gluten free flour blend (I would recommend the source if I recalled where I found it - it was somewhere online - 2 cups rice flour, 2/3 cup cornstarch, 1/3 cup tapioca flour, 1 tsp xanthan gum).  I stopped buying buttermilk years ago and instead make sour milk (3 cups of milk heated in microwave for a minute and mixed with 3 tbsp vinegar then left to sit for 10 minutes). I completely omit the milk from the recipe - the buttermilk always seems to be enough.  Sometimes I toss in blueberries while they cook on the skillet.  Everyone loves them and ask for the recipe.

text:
I made this recipe for a breakfast get together with my family...3 men, 3 women, and 2 kids.  I scaled the recipe to 16 servings thinking I'd have plenty left over to freeze (I mainly did this so I could use my full quart of buttermilk that I knew I wouldn't use otherwise).  We made these pancakes, sausage, eggs, and fruit...all served family style.  We ate it all and we were all very full.  Everyone kept talking about how good they were.  I made about 1/2 the batter plain, and the other 1/2 with blueberries.  They were delicious and I will absolutely make them again.

text:
Awesome recipe.  Easy to make and light and fluffy.  I cut recipe from 12 to 4 servings, only 2 of us. Makes a lot of pancakes.  Subbed oil for butter and added nutmeg and 1/8 cup whole flax seeds to dry batter.  Also added blueberries about a cup.  Mix them with a little of the dry before mixing into batter right before cooking.  great basic recipe. easy to add flavors to it.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-11-18T10:42:18.82

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is FANTASTIC! I was only cooking for me and my fiance, and so scaled the recipe down to 4 servings. The pancakes are very light & fluffy. I cooked them on medium-low in a skillet with melted butter (it adds delicious flavor!) They are so fluffy - IF YOU DON'T OVERMIX. The batter will NOT look like what you get in the box - it will look like a lumpy mess, but don't worry. When it starts cooking, it will fill out and become like a delicious pancake! Five stars!

Delicious! I added about 1 tsp cinnamon to the dry ingredients and about 1 1/2 tsp vanilla to the wet adds. Rave reviews from my hubby & 4 kids.  It would be ideal to have the wet ingredients at room temp so the butter doesn't re-solidify when added to the milk.  Wonderful basic recipe that I'm sure I'll use for many years to come!

text:
I’ am used to making Dutch pancakes and they are very different from the American/Canadian pancakes (flat and big, but tasty). During a visit to Canada last year I tasted the fluffy and thick ‘American-style’ pancakes and ever since I tried to make them this way but without any luck. Finally with this recipe I got it right and it made me (and my family) so happy! Thank you! I believe baking soda is the secret because this is an ingredient that’s not used in the Dutch kitchen and quit hard to get because of that reason. Finding this ingredient (at the Pharmacy!) and using it gave the result I was looking for so long.

userID:
4802662
Display Name:
May L.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Okay, after all my research and wondering if this really was amazing with the 1,200 reviews, I finally scaled the recipe down to two servings so that I could taste it and... my first bite floored me!!!  I just finished my plate and I had to review right away!  They are without a doubt the best pancakes I ever tasted.  I HIGHLY recommend this recipe!  I followed the recipe exactly, and I wouldn't change a thing.  At first I wondered if there was supposed to be vanilla, but I'm glad I didn't need it because the taste is perfect.  I served it with ALLISASMOM's recipe for "Buttermilk Syrup", which is caramelly and vanilla-y.  I would definitely say the adding of the ingredients right before you put them on the griddle, with as little mixing as possible, was the key to the gorgeous fluffy texture.  Awesome.    My advice with the melted butter is to microwave it until *almost* all the butter is melted.  When you mix it up, the solid butter continues to melt in and the result is a cooled liquid butter.  This won't scramble your eggs.  I'm not a "pancake person," but now I am with this recipe.  This is one of those "I know I'll be making every week for my future-children" recipes.  :)  Thank you so very much.

text:
What a great recipe!  I wish I could give it more stars!  As someone who has long given up on boxed pancake mix (hate that stuff) I thought I had been using the perfect Buttermilk Pancake recipe I'd gotten from my Dad over 10 years ago.  I hate to say it but the proportions here are different just enough to edge his pancakes out by 1/2 to 1 star.  I've made these several times and never looked back.  No changes needed except to add seasonal berries if I want.  Leftover pancakes freeze well wrapped in wax paper.  A 50% power zap in the microwave makes them a wonderful weekday treat.  Wish Dad were around to taste these.  I know he'd be impressed.

text:
Scrumdidlyumptious!!! I have made these many times. To insure perfection...keep dry and wet ingredients separate until pan is hot and you are ready. Spoon wet into dry gently just until mixed. Add a few shakes of cinnamon just to give a hint and  vanilla extract. Use real butter to keep pan sizzling to  make pancakes in. I used fat free buttermilk and no regular milk. It turned out delicious light and fluffy. Husband said they've been great before but this time you out did yourself.

text:
There is a reason so many people gave this 5 stars.    As my first ever buttermilk pancake experience, I had no idea what I was in for, especially when the batter appeared lumpy.  My only tip is not to be deterred by the texture of the batter. I got rid of the giant clumps with a fork, but the rest of them just dissapeared in the pan. Go for it!  I also liked adding thin slices of apple once in the pan, was a nice compliment to the buttermilk taste!  Enjoy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had never made anything but boxed pancake mix before, but after making these, I will never make boxed again!  They were so easy, and the texture was perfect.  Moist, fluffy and melt-in-your-mouth good!  And I think this will make a great base for all kinds of pancakes, so I'll have to do some experimenting.  One thing I must say is that the pancakes themselves don't have much flavor, so I think I might add a little vanilla next time, but the texture is just perfect.  UPDATE:  I added a little vanilla extract the 2nd time around and that added the extra lil' something I was looking for.  Soooo good!  Also used another reviewers recommendation and made extra to keep in the freezer.  I just put them in a large ziploc bag and separated each pancake with parchment paper.  Then you can just pop them in the microwave whenever you want.  Of course they're not quite as good as fresh, but still pretty darn good.

delicious!  wonderful old fashioned fluffy pancakes.  honestly, pancakes aren't usually on the top of my list but my husband requested some so I wanted to find a great recipe.  followed the recipe to a t but as another reviewer suggested, added some cinnamon & vanilla.  they were light, fluffy just the right amount of sweetness and overall a 10!  There are only 3 of us so I cut the recipe in half and it was still way more than enough.  I will be making these again.  wow, these are wonderful - thanks for a great recipe.

text:
Definitely my new favorite pancake recipe. I tweaked it a bit but it was a great basic recipe. I tripled the sugar because I like my pancakes on the sweeter side. I didn't have quite enough buttermilk so I added some vinegar to regular milk. Additionally, I would suggest adding the melted butter to the milk before you add the eggs just as another reviewer suggested. Finally, I added a bit of lime juice (I had no lemons) and some vanilla extract. The result, perfect pancakes. :) Enjoy!

I have always wanted to make pancakes without a box mix…these were just fabulous! My whole family (5 of us) loved them! I used fat free buttermilk because that was what I had on hand, and it worked out fine. I found the batter a strange texture, and I was unsure about this recipe at first…but they were just great!!! I agree with the other posts about two things: 1) yes they do taste like IHOP pancakes, and 2) the recipe makes A LOT of batter. So happy I tried these pancakes, the recipe is going in the permanent recipe box!!

text:
Really great base recipe. The one change I made was to separate the egg yolk and whites. I added the yolk to the wet ingredients but whipped the egg whites until soft peaks formed. I folded the egg whites into the combined batter right before cooking. Then dropped some blueberries on top of each cake after pouring onto the skillet. Fluffy, delicious perfection!

text:
The batter makes lovely light and fluffy pancakes.  However, I'd say maybe use 1/3 of a cup of batter per pancake.  When I used 1/2 cup, it came out pretty big and was harder to flip properly.  I don't have a griddle, so had to use a frying pan, which I suppose made a difference.  Cook these up as quickly as you can, because I could notice between the pancakes between the start of the batch, and then end.

My husband made these this morning and they were fantastic!!  The best pancakes I have ever eaten. We love it though!  We just freeze them and pop them in the toaster during the week for a fast breakfast.   Thanks for the great recipe!

The pancakes are fantastic! The best I have come across so far.  The recipe is pretty much flawless.  I make sure to sift my dry ingredients twice, and let my eggs and buttermilk/milk sit out until reaching room temperature for extra fluff. I also add a bit more milk as the batter/cakes are a little too thick as written for our personal tastes. The only thing I added to the recipe was a 1/2 t. of vanilla to the egg mixture before blending everything together.  Thanks so much for submitting this recipe!

Most recipes use veg oil instead of melted butter, and after making these I see why. These tasted fine, but my basic Betty Crocker pancake recipe is 10X easier. It doesn't require buttermilk OR melted butter.

PERFECT!!!  I did as another reviewer suggested and mixed it all up the night before and left it in the frige overnight. So much easier than mixing it in the a.m.!  Made with sausage links and it all came out super yummy, BF is a pancake connisuer and declared them THE BEST! I keep the done ones on a plate in a 225 degree oven to keep them warm while doing the rest so we can sit down and eat all together rather than serving one at a time. Scaled it down to 8 and ended up with 10 good sized pancakes, froze 4 with waxed paper between them for next Sunday =)

text:
This was my first attempt at making pancakes from "scratch." The taste was far superior to that of a mix, but the  consistency of the batter was very thin, and the pancakes turned out flat, not light and fluffy, but soft and spongy.  I'm wondering if it's because I substituted lemon juice in the milk since I didn't have buttermilk.  Although I was disappointed with the texture, I will try again soon, but will use real buttermilk next time to see if that is the problem. The taste merits another attempt -- they're delicious.

text:
I had some buttermilk in my fridge that needed to be get rid of, so I thought that I should try this recipe when I saw it. Little did I know that I would stumble upon the best pancakes I have ever had in my life! I only used 1/3 of the recipe, because my family is small. I ran out of maple syrup, so I increased the sugar amount to 1/4 cup. Also, since I had no milk, I used all buttermilk instead. The batter can be kept in the fridge and used later. I can't wait to try some variations with this recipe!

text:
These were great.  We reduced the recipe to 8 servings hoping to have leftovers to freeze but we ended up eating them all. We followed the recipe exactly for measurements and ingredients.  however we were too hungry to wait for liquid mixture to settle to room temperature so it was a little cool when combined, which is possible why we found some of the pancakes didnb't cook all the way through.  We ended up using slightly less than half a cup per pancake and cooked them on fairly low heat to get them cooked all the way through without sacraficing fluffiness.  Will try again when we are less impatient!!!

I had a craving for pancakes and this far exceeded any and all expectations! I almost don't even want to bother trying anyone else's pancake recipe! Thanks for an amazing recipe!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/745038.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These pancakes are AWESOME. I do have a few suggestions. 1) If you don't keep buttermilk on hand, "sour milk" is a  great substitution. Pour 3 tablespoons of vinegar (any type works!) or lemon juice in the bottom of a large measuring cup and fill with milk to the 3-cup line. Let sit 5+ minutes and use in place of buttermilk. 2) Canola oil and coconut oil work great in place of the butter -- and also save calories! 3) Using half whole wheat flour yields great results. 4) Add a few generous handfuls of quick cooking oats for extra nutrition (this is my kids' favorite variety!). You wont be disappointed!

We make them all the time. TIP: use "Bulgarian Cultured Buttermilk"--much better than standard buttermilk. Also, Splenda works fine here; no need for sugar.   Also: no need to oil the pan if you use Teflon. We use two pans to get the pancakes made more quickly.

Display Name:
irene hillier

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2290404.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Superb recipe!I followed the advice of others and let the milks and eggs sit at room temp before mixing them into the dry ingredients till just combined. Then I let the batter rest for at least 15 minutes, which I read "relaxes" the gluten in the flour and allows the baking powder and soda to act on the flour to produce the desired airiness. Also, as per a reviewer's suggestion, separated the whites from the yolks of the eggs, beat the whites till foamy then gently folded in the liquid mixture. Added a dash of vanilla and cinnamon to the batter, as well as adding more milk about 1/2 cup,since I prefer thinner pancakes. Because of this I ended up with at least 20 pancakes, not counting the ones that got eaten by DH and yours truly. Pancakes were as fluffy as pillows and oh so tender. Delish with vanillin sugar sprinkled on top! Making this recipe does take time to make but the results are well worth the effort.

text:
I followed the recipe exactly and they were the best pancakes I've ever tasted.  I burned my first one and tossed it aside.  While making my next one I nibbled the rejected one.  Even with being burnt on the outside and raw in the middle it was the tastiest pancake ever, so you can imagine how delicious the ones that came out perfectly were.  The pancakes were very fluffy and puffy, not flat at all like some reviews complained of - I suspect the people who got flat cakes didn't follow the direction to stir until *just mixed*, as over-stirring will indeed make them go flat. Once you try this you will not even be able to imagine going back to a box mix.  Just a splendid pancake recipe!

text:
This is by far my favorite pancake recipe and the only one that I make. The only addition that I make is 1/2 tsp vanilla extract.

Update: I have made this recipe many times both using buttermilk and a buttermilk substitute of milk and vinegar. The buttermilk substitute doesn't produce the same thickness of batter and can't recreate the fluffy texture that real buttermilk makes.

text:
Sometimes we like breakfast for dinner so instead of using a mix, I made these pancakes as I had some buttermilk to use up. They were the best pancakes I'd ever made. I followed the recipe exactly, except that I did let my liquid ingredients come to room temperature first, before mixing in with the dry ingredients, as another reviewer suggested. They were light and fluffy and tasted wonderful. I got about 20 pancakes out of this recipe and refrigerated what we didn't eat between sheets of wax paper. I had two for breakfast this morning, heated in the micro-wave, and they still tasted very good. I'll never use a mix again.

text:
Had some leftover buttermilk, so I decided that pancakes were in order this morning!  I scaled this recipe down to four and added 1/2 teaspoon of additional sugar, and dumped everything into the same bowl instead of separating wet and dry ingredients; I was cooking right away.  We loved it!  I made seven hefty pancakes that were fluffy, moist and delicious.  Use REAL buttermilk, don't go trying to make your own with lemon juice or vinegar!  It's not the same and you won't get the same effect.

text:
Very good even though I left out the butter. Did use 1/2 whole wheat flour and "made" my own buttermilk from 1% with enough  white vinegar added to thicken the milk. Also added ~1/2t vanilla extract and let ingredients come to room temp mixing just prior to cooking.  Only criticism was that the batter thinned after sitting a while-(cooked recipe in 2 batches). Maybe a bit less milk next time. (Or maybe if I didn't alter the recipe!)Will definitely make these again.

text:
Great recipe for pancakes. They cooked very evenly and were so tasty. I make a lot of pancakes because my 2 year old loves them so much. I added milk because I like thin pancakes and fresh grated nutmeg because I love the flavor and aroma it adds but not because anything was wrong with the recipe. This is the new pancake recipe for our family now. I was using one from food network but this one is better than the one I was using. For some reason the pancake middles wouldn't cook all the way with the old recipe. This recipe reheats great so I can always have them on hand for my son. I warm them in the toaster.

text:
This was the buttermilk recipe I've been looking for. Really perfect taste, fluffy and light texture.....yum. I made sure to only blend this until just incorporated. That's key for almost any pancake recipe. This scales down really well. I trimmed it down to four and it made seven medium-sized pancakes for my boys and I. Perfect amount. I'll be sure to make this frequently. NOTE: Now when I make these, I use half whole wheat flour and I make the whole recipe. I either use the remaining pancakes to feed my two boys during the week OR I freeze them in batches for a later date. All I have to do is stick them in the microwave and they've got a hot breakfast, paired with fruit and yogurt.

region:

country:
None
text:
Made a half batch of this recipe (Used 2 eggs) and they came out great! This is really a whisk opportunity as opposed to the instructed "using a wooden spoon or fork to blend". I don't know about over stirring but the whisk gets the batter nice and smooth with very few lumps. 
I know everyone loves their short stack but I prefer silver dollars for ease and convenience. These actually cooked faster than my usual dry mix and I was pretty busy poring and flipping. I might try a lower heat next time (was just under medium). Just remember bursting bubbles is your pancake's way of saying "Flip me!"

text:
I was hoping that this recipe would work out for me. It sounded promising. I've been wanting a good homemade pancake recipe. I followed others advice and had the milk and eggs at room tempurature, and I added vanilla for flavor. I followed the directions on the recipe and did not mix dry and liquid until ready to cook. At first it was real fluffy and the first 8 came out great. But then the batter went flat. I don't think I over mixed (I was real careful about this). The following pancakes looked like crepes. Maybe it was because I used margerine instead of butter. And I used 1% milk mixed with lemon juice to substitute for buttermilk. I want to try this again with butter and buttermilk and see how that works. Otherwise, Bisquick is still better.

Well, pancakes are my all time favorite meal and I have always been on the search for the perfect recipe. I have tried everything from Bisquick to Aunt Jemima, from Betty Crocker to the IHOP secret recipe -  and this one is definately the winner! I followed the recipe exactly with the exception of the sugar - I like lots of butter and syrup on the finished product so I only put 2TBSP of sugar in the actual batter. They were fluffy and rich and I can't wait to try and make this recipe as waffles!!

I messed these up, although they still turned out okay.

I scaled the recipe in half (to 6) which called for 1 1/2 eggs.  I didn't know to use 1 or 2, so used 2.

I didn't have buttermilk so substituted 1 cup skim milk with 1 T lemon juice and let it sit for 5 mins (so for 1 1/2 cups I used 1 1/2 T).  When I whisked the wet ingredients, I think the lemon juice "cooked" the egg.  Although you couldn't tell once they were cooked.  

My batter was very very runny (maybe because of the skim milk?) and I ended up adding about 1/3 cup extra flour.  

My first several pancakes were runny, thin, and had an uneven edge.  By the last few pancakes I had adjusted the flour and made them a bit better, but they were still fairly unattractive.  But they did have alot better flavor than the mix.  Because of all the rave reviews I will try this again with real buttermilk, whole milk, and the original amount.
Review:

5

Great pancakes. Not overly sweet, since you only use 3 T of sugar, which is nice since syrup is so sweet. These pancakes are a little spongy, and they taste more like restaurant pancakes than most I've tried. I topped some with syrup and some with strawberries and both were great. Also, they re-heat well in the toaster oven. Try these, you won't be disappointed.

text:
The first thing you have to realize is that there is no buttermilk in this country. Quite the conundrum, wouldn't you say? We made do with runny yogurt, but the pancakes were not fluffy and had a crepe like texture to them. Sort of dense, actually. Still, they tasted just fine and were great served with canned fruit when you can't find budget friendly syrup. All in all, we will probably try this recipe again, perhaps with sour milk.

text:
I took all the ingredients with me on a camping trip last weekend. We had 20 people and they all were raving how delicious the pancakes were. I am now official 'camp cook'. I scaled the recipe for 20 and it worked out perfectly. I was a little short on the buttermilk, but just added a little more milk. one thing I noticed was the batter appeared to go 'flat' by the time I cooked the last couple of pancakes. You couldnt taste a difference , but they were less fluffy.

text:
Haven't tried these for the grandchildren yet, but my husband and I enjoyed them.  The only disappointment was that I saved the leftover batter and when I went to use it the next weekend, it was moldy.  Another recipe suggested that the batter would keep so I was hoping this one would also.  Maybe it would for a day or two, but I don't have a chance to cook a pancake breakfast that often.  We were happy with the taste and texture of this recipe.  Be careful pouring too much batter at oncee, the more batter the bigger the pancake, and the harder to flip.  These were picture perfect. KUDOS.

text:
What I did not like about these pancakes is that they were not as fluffy as I had expected.  They were a little dense and heavy.  Although I liked the taste, two were enough for me.  Some pancakes I don't get sick of.  These, however, satiated me very quickly.  I do not mind that.  That way I eat less.  At this point I am not going to blame the recipe.  Whatever was wrong with them could have very well been the cooks fault.  I will try making them again. They were fun to make. I had never made homemade pancakes.  My children loved them.  They must have eaten six each.  They snitched them from the refrigerator when I was not looking.
